Play this game, never give up.

The game has permadeath, what is why bugs are quite the hell. But despite its age the game is still being developed, bugs get fixed, new features added and with a very active community there are lots of fun mods to help you to get into new things or help with things that are annoying in the base game. You have lots of freedom to explore and build, that make up for the more annoying problems with the game.

One of the best post-apocalyptic zombie survival games I've ever played. Insanely realistic and filled with details, super addictive gameplay, a massive map. Even though there isn't really a goal to do except surviving; there is so many things to do. Only unfortunate part about this game is that developer team is very small and the game has been in early access for around 10 years now, I wish it didn't progress so slow developer-wise but what can you do. Definitely recommended.

Update 2024: This was originally a positive review, but i'm turning this into a negative one now. Here is my reason. This game's build 41 was released in 2021. It has been THREE YEARS since the update was released and the game did not get updated since that. Build 42 was supposed to be small QoL updates and small steps into the NPCs being added to the game. Imagine how long the build 43 would take them, 5 years? 10 more years? This game is clearly abandoned, not being worked on, the money they made isn't being invested back in the game at all. Developers are lazy and don't give a f*ck about the game. I have lost my hope on this game. It gets too dull after a while on it's current state. This was a good experience whatsoever. But this game is done. "Early access" is the cancer of the Steam and the gaming.

This game, it deserves an Award. The graphics may not be the best, but the gameplay makes up for it. As soon as you make your first survivor, you get hooked. And you make a survivor after another, watching them all die. But thats what the game is about, Dying. After all, the menu DOES say, THIS IS HOW YOU DIED. As long as you understand standard zombie culture, this game will appeal. Its good because your not a superhuman with special powers, nor an immune, weapon-having survivor. You're just a Dude, a panicked, sweaty, confused dude. And thats what makes this game good.

I Highly suggest buying this game and playing it. Its worth it.

Retro Arcade Game with the most realistic zombies, this game is best with mods as they really give you the quality of life things that you need. Although past all of that its difficulty is hard as hordes of zombies can easily overpower you and being loud can lead you to your death. The devs really made the game perfect than what it was years ago although they are extremely lazy with the updates and the game feels abandoned at most times.

Very fun game with a sandbox that allows you to play however you choose. Customizable to the point where you can remove the zombies from the zombie game. Realistic game mechanics that make sense for real world physics and progression. Ingame stats do give a boost to things such as sneaking and doing more damage, however a lot of the game is progressed through the real-life players knowledge and skills

Build 41 dropped 3 years ago, and it may be another 3 years until we have access to a stable build with any of the planned features showcased in the monthly newsletter. Personally, I can excuse this because I like the game, even in its current state, but with an update drought this long and no 1.0 in sight I'm hesitant to recommend it outright. If you're interested in Project Zomboid, be mindful of its development trajectory and the likelihood of any additions in the near future. In other words, buy it for what it is, not for what it might be.

This is a game that you could easily pour 1,000 hours into purely because of how high the game's potential is. Stupid developing decisions, many months between updates, jank, etc. all are huge turn-offs for the game. There are mods that try to fix some of the more glaring issues, but in a game that any wound could be lethal, there shouldn't be bugs that cause your car to fly at mock 1000 into the world border, killing you instantly. If vehicles are speed-capped low and/or banned, XP multiplier is high, reading time low, infection chance low, and you have a few buddies, then this game is fing incredible. If you don't have friends to play with, don't get this game unless you enjoy spending hundreds of hours setting up the perfect world just for a bug in game to waste all of it.

A stealth man whos going to be the literal last one still alive, yup thats a way. Wanna be the road warrior using your death machine to plow the roads clear of a hoard, rev that engine and hit 150!!!! The modding community is nothing to sneeze at either when your 5th play through doesnt give you that dopamine hit. Wanna run an armored car? its has your back, wanna up the firepower?.......... Is a ww2 M4 gonna cut it?! Wanna serve the god emperor, your 75mm rocket assisted felchette out of your bolt gun dispenses the emperors mercy in single or full auto. maybe a paperclip rifle is up your alley with a whisper quiet shot you can file 2 or 3 zombies into your "packed" folder. Tired of running solo, theres co-op and you'll see how stalwart your friends can be, will they stand with you on the firing line until the end, or will they take your ride and your food and run for the hills?! The game also is in perpetual development so when irl demands your time the game is nearly brand new when you return to it.

Over 500 hours in now, and Zomboid is absolutely addictive for those that enjoy unfolding games that reward thorough, strategic thinking. The apocalypse is hardly even the most fun part; my penchant for base building, loot hoarding, remodeling, and resource organization are scratched in a way that I've never felt before. Fallout 4 got me with it's junk and settlement system, but the combination of realism and the ever-present danger this game has makes that seem like nothing by comparison. A person could spend a lifetime with just one character exploring and building out the game world... and this game ISN'T EVEN ANYWHERE NEAR it's final form. Upcoming updates for this already vast game are hitting my dopamine buttons like a gerbil with electrodes in its brain. 20/10, and looking forward to what appears to be 100/10 into the future.

I wish I could give it a neutral review. I absolutely adore what this game tried to achieve and it can suck you in for a long time. It is the best zombie survival game I have ever played but I do not think I can recommend it right now. This game has a lot of potential, but it needs more work.

I love the concept and the gameplay of this game. It is the most immersive and realistic zombie survival game I have ever played. It can keep you hooked for hours as you explore, scavenge, craft, and fight. However, the game also has some major flaws that prevent me from recommending it at the moment. The main issue is the lack of end game content and variety. The game becomes repetitive and boring after a while, unless you create your own challenges and goals. The game needs more features and events to keep the player engaged and motivated.

Another problem is the slow and questionable development. The developers seem to focus on minor and irrelevant aspects, such as primitive survival mechanics, instead of addressing the core issues and demands of the community. The most anticipated feature, the NPCs, has been delayed for too long and there is no clear roadmap or timeline for its release.

This game was once a burning passion of mine and it most likely will be again depending on what updates we receive. I do hope that the developers focus points do not come at a detriment of the games absolute massive potential.

"Project Zomboid is an absolute gem in the world of zombie games, offering unparalleled depth, realism, and challenge that keep players engaged for hours on end. Its immersive survival mechanics, dynamic world, and strategic decision-making set it apart from cookie-cutter zombie titles that rely on cliches and repetitive gameplay. In comparison, most other zombie games pale in comparison, lacking the depth, complexity, and sheer ingenuity that makes Project Zomboid a true standout in the genre."

I enjoy this game's challenging take on a zombie apocalypse that other games tend to miss. You're not a invincible bad ass with plot armor who can seemingly survive anything thrown against them. I'm not saying those games are bad. They don't really focus on the weight of the fact that the world has ended, and you must now survive the ever loving hell that is the apocalypse through what you have left. 

Games like Left 4 Dead aren't so much about trying to survive everyday life. They are more focused on killing hordes of the infected and reaching an end goal. Cod Zombies, the opposite end of the spectrum, is killing hordes of zombies but with no end goal for the player except death. Like I said before, these games aren't bad, and I have loved them all throughout my childhood. 

But the difference between those games and Project Zomboid is that you aren't the characters from Left 4 Dead, and you aren't the characters from Cod Zombies who have sustained thousands of zombies without so much of blinking an eye. You are just an everyday person who one day woke up to the end of the world. Now, with the prior knowledge of everyday life before you, you must use this knowledge to better survive against the undead. 

Loot doesn't come easy. Guns are a death wish. Zombies are dangerous no matter how fast or slow they are, and one day YOU WILL DIE. Death is inevitable in this game, and Project Zomboid doesn't shy away from it. It embraces that fact. It doesn't matter the hours you have on this game or not. Death is certain in this apocalypse. The only thing we can do is delay the inevitable...

It's a game that I come back to over and over again and get completely demolished in every time, it's very fun (when you can get at least an hour into a run) except for one single detail. It never feels fair, even though every death is technically avoidable, because the game chooses what you mean by one of it's most vital button prompts, and it is only usually correct, which is not even close to good enough when you're inches from death. This detracts significantly from your ability to control the situation and makes it play a little bit like a rage game.

For an example, imagine you are fighting too many zombies right now, like a good number that you could just barely handle if your guy did what you wanted him to. You're unarmed and don't have any skills, but the situation is very well survivable and you have a reasonable strategy. You will push them to the ground as they approach, see if you can jab them with a pen in the process, but get them on the ground and then stomp one of them at least once when they're all down.

You shove by pressing space (keep that in mind), or whatever button you have bound, and there's a reasonable chance (but no guarantee) that this pushes the zombie over. You then stomp them to kill them (again, no guarantee this works immediately). The reason this controls like a rage game is because the stomp button is also space, but bindings can't fix this because they are literally the same action, they can not be bound separately, and shoving takes precedence not when you're looking at a standing zombie, but whenever a standing zombie is nearby, even a good few feet behind you or off to the side (I'm not exactly certain, please excuse a little imprecision about the technical details, I have only lost maybe 12 runs this way).

This is the exact point where the game transitions from intense moment to complete nonsense which robs you of another character. A zombie is on the ground, another is approaching from the opposite side of you, and you've just turned to the latter zombie in order to gauge it's distance before your next move. You turn around to face the vulnerable zombie, but not all the way, only so far that the stomp will connect. You press the stomp button and. . . and you shove out at open air.

Not at the approaching zombie, and also not at the zombie on the floor. This couldn't have benefited you, and it's not what you were trying to do. This wasn't a wrong decision on your part; you did all you could do by pressing the stomp button. The **STOMP SLASH SHOVE** button. During your retarded flailing, the zombie approaching closes massive distance, and the one on the ground is already getting up (your chance is gone by a wide margin, there is no recovery).

You will continue to fight ineffectively, mimicking this pattern, until someone gets a bite in as the horde inevitably grows from noise throughout the painfully, infuriatingly dragged out conflict. This is pervasive because the game reserves the right to interpret what you mean by the button press, literally not allowing you to make the distinction yourself, but it is always more wrong than you are about what you're trying to do. I can not recommend the game exclusively because the space button performs two very different and mutually exclusive functions at the most critical times in gameplay, and does not allow you to make the distinction yourself, all-too-often ending your run in completely avoidable situations.

Project Zomboid is the most realistic game I've ever played and probably the only game I'll play where I start a new game after losing a 20 hour character. There's no goal other than survival, and you get to choose how you accomplish that. Anything you can think of is a viable option that's been fully realized by either the devs or the legions of modders. You can build a fort inside a mall, drive across the state as a nomad, or live a quiet life at home eating your cabbage. There's so much depth while the game itself remains very easy to get into. Not only is the map big and full of towns (which are in turn full of buildings and zombies to explore and fight), there's tons of items, vehicles, and weapons to collect and use, and you can customize your character and the game settings quite extensively. All these tools in the sandbox allow you to play whatever zombie game/movie/media you want. You can go for something slow burn or you can choose to go in guns blazing. If something happens to be missing or you just want [i] more [/i] then there's tons of great mods that you can easily install from the workshop. These range from entirely new maps to new clothing and guns. Honestly the game isn't really something to read about or watch a video on, it's something you have to play for yourself and get immersed in.

In a way, this is kinda like Day Z but isometric.  I got into this game from my former roomate.  While I was hesitant and stubborn to play it at first, I quickly got into it.  The game can be brutally difficult.  Think of something like S..T.A.L.K.E.R but you're an average Kentucky citizen in the early 90's.  The game doesn't hold you hand, and doesn't care if you die.  That being said, I mostly play custom sandbox.  Playing singleplayer is depressing af (until Indie Stone adds NPCs) but multiplayer is where it's at.  I've probably had some of the wackiest moments with me and the boys in PZ multiplayer.  Coupled with the great modding community?  You're in for a real treat.  What game allows you to roleplay as an Ryan Gosling from Drive 2011, while listening to the most cursed music imaginable, you're passenger firing an AK out the passenger window on the interstate?  This game.  With the amount of mods for this game..it kinda reminds me a lot of L4D2.  Mods are probably the only thing keeping this game alive in between updates and that's fine.  And the best part is you can customize your game to your liking.  This game has near endless possibilities.  And while there is no real end goal currently, there's plenty of mods to fill that void

Pretty solid game deserving of its favourable reviews, even as someone who had to painstakingly play this without a mouse.

Another review down here noted that instead of acting as some sort of enhanced, superpowered entity, you are playing as a regular individual who is stressed-out, panicking, hungry, and tired. You get various advantages to choose from, which must be offset by disadvantages, so that your character ends up being thoroughly balanced. The game mechanics itself may seem simple at first, with the process of killing a zombie not requiring much skill, but there is a fair bit of survival instinct that must be employed if you wish to avoid alerting all the zombies in the area and being quickly overwhelmed.

The survival portion is huge and forces you to stay constantly aware of multiple factors at a time. Breaking into a window can result in broken glass that cuts you, and if that cut goes untreated, can become infected and develop into something much more dangerous. Food can replenish your hunger but stale food can adversely affect your happiness levels. Failing to clean up blood after killing zombies can attract more zombies and result in a horde, and so on. Ultimately, this game is worth the shot as it isn't particularly pricey and its multifaceted nature can keep you up for long periods, especially when playing with friends.

This is what a game made with real creativity, passion and dedication looks like. I am so happy games like Project Zomboid are being made and worked on. It has an amazing modding community and online presence like on Youtube. I wanted to play this game for a couple of years before buying it and I'm so happy I did. The ability to learn how to use all the systems in the game and enjoy roleplaying appeals to me so much. I would love to see the multiplayer options being improved in the coming years as the UI to access it isn't all that user friendly and the downloading countless mods to try a new server can get pretty boring. I think Project Zomboid has huge potential as a multiplayer game but at the moment I consider it a requirement to know the people you're playing with prior to entering a server, I think that the community could really benefit from an environment where people are getting to know each other through playing Zomboid.

A brutal approach to the Zombie survival game. The little things matter.  Survival isn't expected.  You're meant to die, over and over until you learn your character limits, the gameplay mechanics, and environmental factors that keep you alive and safe.  Don't let the simple looking graphics fool you.  The world is enormous and the map, homes and points of interest are painstakingly detailed.

My best advice for new players that quickly get overwhelmed, start your next game in "sandbox" mode, and scale down the difficulty while you learn the ins & outs.  Its your sandbox to decide what is fun and what isn't.

Happy surviving!

Not sure how to exactly feel about this game yet. Conceptually, it's one of the finest zombie-apocalypse games I've ever played. Yet, on the other hand, small UI and gameplay features take me out of the game as strongly as its best features suck me in. 

Long story short, Steam could really use a mixed recommendation between "yes" and "no."

My main issues rely on combat, with melee being a bit finicky at times, though isn't something which is too hard to adapt to. Guns are another issue, however, which are darn near unplayable without high skills and/or mods. I feel that the movement penalty is a bit harsh at times, and that close quarters gunplay is far more inaccurate than it should be regardless of skill. I can understand it from a balance perspective, but it's still annoying.

My last issue lies with the moodles, most of which I love but some feel really intrusive and out of place. Depression and boredom just feel kinda stupid considering the circumstances, like I have far bigger issues than to be bored. Panic also annoys me, as it often pops up when I as a player feel none, breaking my sense of immersion. It's hard to line these up with how a player feels, but having them feel so out of place is a genuine annoyance, especially considering they debuff my character.

As I said, I love the game and will continue playing it, but its hard to recommend for others when considerable modding and configuration may need to be done to compensate for some of the flawed mechanics.

Title: Survival Horror Masterpiece

Project Zomboid isn't just a game; it's an immersive journey into the heart of survival horror. From the moment you step into its post-apocalyptic world, every decision matters. The atmosphere is tense, the stakes are high, and the undead hordes are relentless.

What sets Project Zomboid apart is its unforgiving realism. You're not a superhero here; you're an ordinary person trying to survive against insurmountable odds. Every action, from scavenging for supplies to fortifying your hideout, requires careful planning and resource management. One wrong move, and it could be your last.

The game's sandbox nature means that no two playthroughs are ever the same. Whether you're hunkering down in a remote farmhouse or braving the streets of a zombie-infested city, every decision you make shapes your story. And with the addition of multiplayer, you can team up with friends to increase your chances of survival or betray them in the pursuit of your own goals.

But perhaps the most impressive aspect of Project Zomboid is its commitment to realism. The game doesn't hold your hand or pull any punches. You'll need to contend with hunger, thirst, sickness, and mental health issues, all while fending off the undead and other survivors. It's a brutal, unforgiving world, but one that rewards ingenuity and perseverance.

In conclusion, Project Zomboid is a true survival horror masterpiece. With its deep gameplay, immersive atmosphere, and relentless challenge, it's a must-play for any fan of the genre. Just remember: in the world of Project Zomboid, death is always just around the corner.

This game is hard. This game is unforgiving. This game is realistic in a strict sense of the word.
You are going to die. Each death is a lesson learned. You must be careful with every decision.

When you die, you lose that character- stats and all- and start anew. However, the world/map is persistent. You start over in the same map from a random location. Your new character can stumble upon your old base and supplies- even your old characters groaning-zombie body.

There is a mode in this game where you can customize absolutely every aspect of your experience. If you like The Walking Dead and slow moving zombies (but numerous), customize the game and zombies to resemble that universe. If you like 28 Days Later where the zombies come at you full sprint, customize the game and zombies to resemble that universe. 
In this way, between customization and realism this is easily the greatest z-game ever made.

I genuinely do not know why I haven't played this game WAY sooner. It is everything I love about zombie games. The absolute freedom you have in setting up a base anywhere is rather neat. 53 hours in and I haven't made it past day 10...

I love the experience of looting neighborhoods, scavenging restaurants, grocery stores in all the freedom you have to literally do whatever you want. I think my favorite thing is that you can change almost any setting to make the experience you want to have. I have the zombies being shamblers only, the infection only spreading through bites and it can still be overwhelming at times. The learning curve is rather steep but when you learn, you can really feel an actual difference in your skill. It might take a few deaths, but eventually you will be capable on handling more than 1 zombie at once. 

I tend to start over entirely when I die, taking what I learned from my past life to hopefully last longer. I am currently in a multiplayer server with a buddy and it is the most fun I have had in a game in a long while. I love how incredibly dangerous everything is. I still play fully vanilla and honestly need to try mods; however, I genuinely enjoy the vanilla experience. 

I have seen that the devs are VERY slow to release updates but I am going to have a little faith in them. What this game is right now is nothing short of brilliant, artistic, and an absolute blast. 

My buddy and I are planning a Louisville trip soon and I am kinda nervous.... I love when a game can fill me with this kind of "real" stress about doing a task like this.

Who knew that preparing for the end of the world could be so hilariously stressful? Project Zomboid did. This game is not just a survival horror; it's a crash course in post-apocalyptic life management, with a minor in carpentry and a specialization in culinary arts (because who doesn't want to master the art of making a stir-fry during a zombie apocalypse?).

From the get-go, Project Zomboid sets the tone: "This is how you died." Well, excuse me for my optimism, but after my 47th death, I began to think of it more as "This is how you learned to barricade a window with a fridge." The game's commitment to realism is admirable, if not slightly concerning. Ever wanted to learn how to disinfect a rag with whiskey? Project Zomboid has got you covered. Need to figure out how to hotwire a car while being chased by a horde of the undead? There's a skill book for that.

The game's open-world, combined with its intricate crafting and building systems, makes for an experience where every playthrough feels unique. One day you're a fisherman, living off the land and sea, peacefully coexisting with nature. The next, you're a katana-wielding, bear-trap-laying madman, screaming into the night as you're overrun by zombies because you forgot to turn off the oven.

But it's not just about surviving the zombies; it's about surviving boredom, loneliness, and the gradual decline of your character's mental health. The game's depth in simulating life (or what's left of it) post-apocalypse is both its charm and its curse. Watching your character develop a fear of the dark because you made them read too many books at night without a light is both hilarious and heartbreakingly realistic.

Project Zomboid teaches you valuable lessons, like how not to get attached to anything, especially your base, your supplies, or, well, your life. It's a constant reminder that no matter how fortified your fortress is, it only takes one overlooked back window for your cozy safehouse to turn into an all-you-can-eat buffet for zombies.

In conclusion, Project Zomboid is a masterclass in survival horror, blending meticulous detail with dark humor. It's a game where your most memorable moments will come from the smallest victories and the silliest deaths. Whether it's accidentally drinking bleach instead of water or heroically dying while trying to save your crops from a horde, Project Zomboid is a game that keeps on giving. 10/10, would accidentally set myself on fire trying to cook a rat again.

Zomboid is a brilliant game, in a sort of "engine" "sandbox" and "project" way. Nearly every number within the game is customisable, and the player is thrown into a story of how they die. But they can survive, farm, build, mod and customise all the events of that story. Very replayable, because it is so open ended that you set your goals. The style and the little humorous details bring a sort of arcade feel to an otherwise very depressing, brutal and bleak characters life, making slaying undead a good bit of fun. 

Game is STILL in early access, so the only problem (personally) is that the game isn't quite finished yet! But for such a flexible game, other people in the community pick up slack, and even create beyond anything you'd expect in a "zombie" game.

The trailer does perfectly encapsulate what this game is about. It's a very freedom-based survival sandbox that puts emphasis on looting and realism. The combat is fun and enjoyable, but making a base and slowly building it up is the bread of this game. Visiting other areas like Military Bases and whole capital cities is another ordeal in itself. Eventually, this is a game that takes the absolute cornerstones of a drained genre and brings it to new light, by combining simple gameplay with complex systems. The results is frustrating in short-term, but incredibly rewarding long-term, but it seems like the best version of the game is a few updates away. I'd recommend buying it NOW, then fully investing time into it once it's more polished. That being said, its still incredibly enjoyable.

What you see on the box is what you get. They've got some PvP, PvE, and RP communities to keep things varied on top of the option for just local play. The devs have worked pretty consistently on this game since it's been published and continue to do so with new and interesting additions which is further supported by the [i]incredibly active[/i] modding community. 

All in all, if you like urban zombie nonsense, survival, and don't mind a more simplistic combat system, it's absolutely worth the price and will only get better as more comes out.

Playing this game is very enterntaining, addictive and never repetitive.
You can find yourself doing almost anything you'd imagine doing in the real world.
Playing alone can get boring, but with people it is all the hype.
There is so much you can do, such as you can build and barricade your own base,
you can unite with people to go on scaveging runs, fight zombies & create epic stories,
roleplay, auto-service vehicles & challenge yourself with different restrictions to your gameplay, as you can arrange your playthrough just the way you would like to, and not to mention all of the other many, many things you can do in this wonderful game such as cook, tailor, collect, forage & fish. It is the most realistic zombie game i have ever played, and truly my all-time favorite. With this huge, vast open map, there is basically infinite replayability. All of these mods... They just make the experience even better.
in conclusion, i would totally recommend this game for anybody interested in the most realistic and most fun, open zombie survival experience.

Open World Survival in a 3/4 isometric view. It's a very harsh survival world and the difficulty of it is a huge selling point. It does what a lot of FPS based zombie apocalypse games fails to by truly making you afraid of everything... From a small scratch getting infected to opening a door.

Great suspense built directly into the game.

Please get this game. 

You can get in any building you see in this massive open world. You can loot every cabinet, and every surface. Build so many structures and plant so many things to help you survive. If you die, you can find the spot you set up and start all over again.

I understand if this game feels unforgiving at first. Though the more you play the better you will get at everything. You will eventually be able to take on larger and larger hoards of zombies. smash through them with cars (If you have the keys, or gas or I assume with enough skill the ability to hotwire). 

This game takes so much into consideration. If you smash a window it will make noise and alert zombies. If you climb in through that window you will get cut if you don't clear the glass. You get tired if you don't rest. You will get hungry if you don't eat, and if you are munched on by the hoard, you will come back to life as just one more zombie you will have to deal with.

There aren't currently any goals or missions in this game except survive and kill as many zombies as you can in one life. I think I survived for over a day and only killed a max of 21 zombies in that time. However, I play super aggressively and tend to stumble on enemies and don't rest enough.

Almost anything can become a weapon. Got a pen? Guess what, you can stab zombies with it. You can also use it to mark your map. It's not the best weapon, its not mightier than a sword in this instance. You can however, finds loads of different weapons that are more effective and need to be maintained to function over time, but be warned... GUNS attract LOTS of zombies.  

Like I said. Get this game. YOU WILL LOVE IT! YOU WILL HATE IT! But more than anything, YOU WILL DIE. It just depends on when and how.

PS. The more people that grab this the more the developers can invest in fleshing it out! Please support the development team!

Project Zomboid is difficult, unforgiving, and clunky at times, but I think that's part of what makes it great. Solid game though. 7/10

I bought this game 11 years ago. 

I've been a big fan for a long time, but sadly, I cannot recommend this game. 

Why? 

Because its built on a throne of lies. 

What are the lies? 

That this is the most amazing immersive zombie survival game on the market. 

I'll keep it short and simple:

The early game is 10/10. 
All the people who review this, giving this positive reviews, are people who have only played the early game. 

They haven't reached the mid-end game, where there is LITERALLY NOTHING TO DO. 

LITERALLY, it becomes "Sit around and grow crops and do nothing simulator". 

The sycophantic community that supports this game, are people that haven't played the game long enough to understand the *severe lack of mid-end game content*. 

They started off so strong and you could tell the passion was there when they started. But it seems like moneys just rusted the gears of progress and they just don't care anymore and they're just throwing in some token effort to create the illusion that this game is still getting worked on when in reality its not getting the love it deserves.

When I first bought this game, I didn't mind that this was a fact, I understood, its early access and that more features would surely come in due time. 

That was 11+ years ago. 

What have they added since then thats been significant?

Two things: Vehicles and... multiplayer, which the VAST MAJORITY of players do not even care for. 

I made these complaints, after 11 years of supporting this game, in the forums. 

The main mod, Mad Dan, decided that my criticisms were verboten, and banned me from the forums because I was "asking for it". 

Cool story dude, is what what you say about sexual abuse survivors too? 

All I did was give *very fair criticism* of the state of the game after 11 years. 

And that is enough to get you banned if you dare tell the mods "You do it for free". 

Try Cataclysm: Bright Nights, which is completely free and is everything zomboid was trying to be and do better, and has now, after 11 years, failed miserably at except with the graphics part.

Catalysm is superior in every way if you're willing to look past the graphics and turned based nature.

Edit: As it turns out, I'm not the only person whose been banned from the forums for criticizing the game. 

Other people have messaged me after reading this review to tell me the same fate happened to them when they asked questions and criticized the game. 

As it turns out, the community does not like it when you point out the flaws of this game, and will screech and ree at you for doing so until Mad Dan decides you are now voted off the island. 

Stay away from this toxic and sad community unless its to troll them about "11 years and still no NPC's."

Edit 2:

Lets turn this into a speed run to see how long it takes to get you banned by pointing it out. 
That's about as much fun as you can have once the glow of early game zomboid wears off.

Here's a list of things you can do to get banned from the forums-

How to speed run getting banned from Project Zomboid:

Talk/ask about future builds.

Point out the fact there is no mid-end game content. 

Point out the fact that hardly anyone plays this game for the multiplayer and that the multiplayer is poorly done and that mods break it. 

Point out the modding community is the only thing keeping this game alive.

Point out the hundreds of mods that make the game significantly better that are still lore friendly that have basically been given the devs for free which they refuse to implement.

Point out that NPC's are the #1 requested feature for the last 11 years and they still haven't implemented them.

Point out that the mods for NPC's kill your FPS because there is no optimised framework that allows for NPC's.

Point out that most of the skills are useless. (When will you ever use first aid? Hint: You don't.)

Point out there is only one skill that matters and thats the ability to hotwire cars and you've pretty much hit "end game" if you can do this since cars are OP and you can basically live out of them. 

Once you get banned from the forums, you can still continue to message MadDan on the subject you got banned on if you go to the bottom which allows for comments that go straight to MadDan now and remind him that he does it for free.

When I first got this game, I'd seen a short clip of someone playing in a video. I was interested, so I bought the game and tried it out. At first, it struggled to hook me in. I was actually planning to refund it completely, but that was when I accidentally went over the two hour limit. I knew refunding then would only be a pain, so I decided to give it another chance. I will never feel that was about this game ever again.

I don't know what happened, but one day this game just held me in its grasp for an entire week as I lived through the body of the virtual survivor on my screen. People give this game a lot of credit, but I would like to point out just how easily it can hook you in for hours upon hours, just to see your survivor's life through. This game, although straight out telling you you are going to die, makes death almost seem like the final goal. 

You're telling a story. You are the survivor. This is Project Zomboid.

This game for me is one of the best or if not the best zombie games out there. When I first heard of this game it was from a french friend that barely spoke any english and I bought it to play with him, I play it with him for a while rage quit like a little baby and dont touch it for months.
Then I eventually was scrolling through my steam library looking for a game to play and decided to play it and let me tell you this game will hook you in and you cant get out.

The gameplay in this game is the best out of all the other zombie games I played and thats saying a lot since ive been in the zombie game scene for a while and have played many of them and this one specifically has stuck out for me as the ultimate jack of all trades one. Everything from the weather, combat, building, and hell even grinding for skills is just fucking fun.

I really find this game enhanced when you start to implement mods in your playthroughs it just adds lots of more gameplay possibilities to the game to a already chock full game, some mods make the game way harder than it should be and for a masochist like me it really makes the game fresh such as one mod that makes the fog toxic.

Some people put this game down for the grapics and I really dont agree with it, I think the graphics simply improve the game because its a decently indepth game by itself, take rimworld for example, that game has a injury system but the injurys or bandages dont show on the modles even though its 2d but it does in zomboid. And I really find that the graphics are friendly for lower end PC users that have problems running higher end games

The gameplay loop is almost limitless due to character builds in multiplayer, since in character creation you have to balance positive and negative traits it adds a new depth of difficulty to this already pretty hard game.

The multiplayer in this game is what really hooked me in and kept me playing, the interactions with other players wheather it be surviving or riddling someone else with bullets its always fun no matter the day, combined with the nice community that will help you out with the game its just all in all friendly.

Difficulty in this game to describe it the best i can is easy to learn hard to master, Newer players will have a hard time understanding PVP and it can take over 500 or 1000 hours to fully master but oh so its ever worth it, The other mechanics is also pretty easy to learn for a begginer such as first aid and bandaging wounds, its just slap a bandaid on it or if its a deep wound just stich it up.

I would say the atmosphere in this game is also excellent, in my own personnel experiance I havent seen much zombie games set in kentucky, and at first i didnt like it when i first started but I love it now, when you enhance the game with map mods it gets even better such as map mods like "Raven creek" or "Eeerie county" You can really mod the hell out of this game to make it for you, Want to make it into a stalker type survival simulator? you can do that!, want to have a 10 years later survival story with over grown buildings? you can do that aswell. 

This game is truely limitless and even if you dont think you would like this game I beg you to give it a chance because you wont regret it and you will love it, and well if you dont you can flay me alive in my steam comments for all i care and I will still stick by my word that this is the best zombie survival game out there.

Try this game out!!!!!

Project Zomboid. Never have I played a game that captures the realism of a zombie apoclypse quite like this game. It's pixelated, and at times quite bueatiful. However, it has it's fair share of bugs, which is to be expected from a game like this, but none are game breaking or anything like that. But I have to say, I have NEVER been this into a zombie game before, which is shocking becuase I adore zombie games.  Now To start the Pros and Cons:

Pros: The game is incredibly immersive, with one huge overworld. While there are multiple starting points, they are all on the same map. The base building is quite enteraining, if not a little confusing. It took me a few playthroughs to understand it in full, but once you get it, it's really rewarding to build up your base. And if thats not enough, it has multiplayer servers, some of which are simply for roleplay. It's crafting system is diverse, and its zombie AI is quite good.

Cons: It's very much a "niche" game, something enjoyed in small bursts usually. It is also buggy at times, but that is to be expected from a game that is constantly being updated, and who's creators are decicated to the project. Just be warned though, there IS a learning curve with this game, and it can be difficult at times. Also the combat can be a bit.. wonky.

All that being said, I feel compelled to give this game a 7/10. It's an incredible game, and worth your time and money.


***MASSIVE UPDATE, writing this nearly 7 years later.

This game is a 11/10 now, the best zombie game I have ever played and ever will play. I don't just recommend it, you *need* this game. Do you like the sims? Do you like the walking dead? Do you like base building? Do you like MODS? This game gives fucking *skyrim* a run for its money with its mod community. Get it. Seriously.

I have played this game for over 100 hours so far and I can say that it is worth the $20. In this game you can play solo and experience what it is like to be the sole survivor of a zombie apocalypse knowing that no one is coming to save you and that you will have to find a way to provide for your nutritional needs, or you can play with your friends to form groups and increase your chances of survival. 

This game has a little bit of everything for whatever type of play you want.
-Want to be a mechanic? Take parts off a car and repair them with your metalworking skill or find other cars to part out.
-Want to build bases? You can level up your carpentry and make post apocalyptic bases or design the house of your dreams that you cant afford in real life. 
-Want to be a vagabond? Find a car with a key/ hot-wire one and roam town to town gathering what you need to survive.

I will admit that the game has a steep learning curve and that when I first played I stopped after dying 3 times with-in the first 2 hours but if you are struggling you can take a break and watch some tips and tricks videos on YouTube and get back in that saddle ready to go.

P.S. for all of you who want to mod your games, the main menu has an option to download mods and it makes it easy to add or remove mods from different saves.

I've survived more than a year on a character and I can assure you there is more than enough food on the map to live 10 years without farming, fishing or trapping. You'll eventually die to nonsense even if you're a good player, such as doors on a car not shutting but there is no animation to warn you *shakes fist at sky*.

So ultimately the game is a test of how long you can be alone. While there is multiplayer, that format has issues which can be just as challenging to get over as the loneliness in single player such as desync (screen will turn black and freeze until things load) and zombie count limitations.

When you decide to buy or not buy this game, completely ignore any promises from the developers on what is coming "soon." There is no soon, as they have decided to take as long as they want to develop their game. That is their prerogative, but as a consumer you should be informed on what that means. They have been promising animals and npcs for 10 years. TEN YEARS. The title of the game is "project" for a reason and it is never going to leave early access. NEVER. I've lost confidence in the studio's ability to ever be able to overhaul their existing code (imagine working on the same code for over a decade and NOT having it become spaghetti). Just on the basis that every UI in the game is different it should be obvious to everyone they don't have a solid code base.

So if you want to challenge yourself for a few hundred hours solo or forever in modded multiplayer, know that these have their limitations and there is no update coming from the developers in a realistic time period to address those issues. Play the game for what it is today with its faults, or don't. Just don't fall for the upcoming content unless you plan on watching your grandchildren play some day from a rocking chair.

the zomboids be zomboiding

I'll start by saying that I am not a fan of survival games. I'm also very wary of early access. Project Zomboid broke the mold in both cases.

Most survival games that I've played, even ones with consistent elements of danger, have felt like chore simulators. Project Zomboid's implementation of survival mechanics is something else entirely, however. The slow shamblers of Romero films, which Zomboid's default settings are based on, are the ultimate persistence hunters. Here, the survival aspects enhance this. They aren't just a chore. They're what makes the game worth coming back to.

The game has an incredible number of customization options, and that's before taking user created mods into consideration. 

It's also incredibly in depth. Let me give you an example:
My current character is living out of his car - The back seats are filled with canned food, ammunition for his guns, books on survival basics and more. Last night he pulled into what I thought was a middle of nowhere gas station on the back roads of Kentucky. It was getting late, he needed to refill his water bottles, refuel his car, and maybe find something to eat in the gas station before finding somewhere to get some sleep. There was one or two zombies lurking outside the station, but - no biggie, I figured he'd just quickly pop them with his rifle and be on his way. Shouldn't be too many out there.

If I'd driven just a little bit further down the road, I'd have seen the larger parking lot of a nearby diner, the street that turned into a tightly packed cul-de-sac. Two shots rang out, the gas station's pumps began to hum to life as he started refueling his car... And a horde lurched around the fence into view. He hopped in his car and sped off, dead limbs catching in the wheel well and nearly grinding them to a halt. One of the headlights went out from the impact, the other had a dead bulb from before he ever found the car. The sun was setting, it was getting dark, and speeding off down the road he slammed into a tree.

The engine won't turn over now, his wrist is broken - so even if he's a crack shot with a rifle it won't be much use for him. He's got one bottle of water left, and nothing he might need to start repairing his engine. It's going to be a long walk back to town in the morning, a town I know now is swarming with zombies, and just in the hopes of finding some basic supplies alongside, hopefully, a wrench, a book on mechanics, and maybe a vhs tape that will cover the basics of car repair.

There are other survival games out there. I've tried a lot of them, even if survival games aren't my bag - because I've been looking for the authentic zombie apocalypse experience. None of them come close to the kind of considerations and decision making that come up in Project Zomboid.
Is it worth 20$? Definitely. Honestly, even in early access I think it's already well worth more.

This game is unlike any zombie survival games I have played, but truthfully, I haven't played some of the popular games like 7 Days to Die. I really got on with State of Decay and State of Decay 2 (shout out for the upcoming third entry).

If you like the struggle of the zombie apocalypse, this game is for you. It rewards exploration, ingenuity, and sometimes even just plain old determination.

If you don't enjoy learning and getting better through innumerable times of starting over and retrying, this game is not for you. You will struggle. You will die. You will be rewarded knowledge through each death. Sometimes the same death, but you may learn a different thing.

If you are used to using a controller, this game is going to be hard, but it is worth the slog of dying over and over to finally survive a day, then two days, and eventually maybe even a week. You get out of it what you put in so get out there and die, die again.

Shockingly reduces the weight of wood if you're not a fan of making so many trips.
this one has 25% , 50% and 75% versions if you only want to reduce it slightly, or alot.

[b] - Noirs Rifle Strings [/b]
Cosmetic that you can string across your chest or waist that can hold a second rifle. 
I use this a lot to run a shotgun/rifle combo.

[b] - Noirs Backpacks [/b]
Creates attachment slots for things on backpacks. Packs are upgradable, can hold up to 12 items; things like water bottles (2), a saw, a plushie(?), and a couple free slots for miscellaneous tools like wrenches and hand axes.

[b] - Reorder Hotbar [/b]
what it says lol

[b] - Rain Cleans Blood [/b]
different from rain cleans clothes, as this mod specifically cleans the ground of blood stains if it rains for long enough
Super fun once you get good at it

You remember when you watched the Walking Dead and told yourself how you'd do things differently and never get yourself into this situation and how the characters are all a bunch of fools. Project Zomboid really lets you test your mettle.

Zomboid is a fantastic survival top down game that has realistic functions that you would expect with a real life situation. Sure it doesn't have EVERYTHING, but the Dev team is also amazing in that fact as they constantly update the store page with exciting new builds and upcoming features. Would highly recommend joining a community server or playing with featured mods as well as they can vastly broaden your experience but are not necessary to enjoy the game. But I would say, play with friends for the full experience!

My soon to be a Zomboid identifies as a straight white horny heteroseuxal male. You can find him strapped with a crowbar, fleshlight, and anime pillow. He's always looking for quiet time. Nothing is more annoying than putting the psp down to go bash some zombies. It's a ton of fun to mow them down, bury them, and hide once again by your lonesome to toke the bong. This is not a game that you expect to use a ton of resources, until you realize it's a bit of a Sim 3 clone. It's easily the best version of that game but comes with a lot of those limitations. For example, you can drive a car but going fast will lag the game. I give 5 stars to the modding community that saved this from being a lost cause. Eventually you'll add so many mods that starting a game without an error is a badge of honor you share with friends. This is an early access game from 2013 so be prepare to modify files to bring it up to a respectable level.

Project Zomboid plays less like a video game and closer to something like D&D. It has an amazing ability to react to and support what the player tries to do, with fidelity that rivals a human DM.

What would you do in the zombie apocalypse? Many survival games try to let you answer this question, but they often end up so restrictive. Even in an open world, there‚Äôs a certain way to survive that the game will lead you towards.

The mechanics in those games feel so unsubtle, and there are normally one or two main systems everything else revolves around that you have to engage with.

Project Zomboid, with it‚Äôs sheer volume and depth of systems, avoids this railroading. It‚Äôs actually jarring when you first start playing, because you‚Äôre approaching it like it‚Äôs a video game. You leave your house expecting to find a gun right away like every other game.

You expect the game to throw you a bone, you expect that railroad to appear and lead you to the primary few mechanics that is the focus of the game.

And expecting this, you‚Äôre going to die. And it‚Äôs going to feel weird. What did I do wrong? Where are the mechanics? What I‚Äôm I supposed to do?

What would you do in the zombie apocalypse?

Draw your curtains. Take inventory of what you have in your house. Take peeks out the window or watch the news for information. Start thinking about food and water. Make a plan.

Stop treating this game like it‚Äôs a game, and you‚Äôll hit your stride.

I think that‚Äôs a beautiful accomplishment for a game to achieve.

Project Zomboid is the game I have always wanted since I have grown a passion for the zombie genre. Starting with George A Romero's sense of this is a normal person telling the story of how they died or lived long enough to see yourself become the rugged villainous survivor. Doing anything to ensure we wake up the next day. The developers keeping the passion burning for all these years and are so close yet to another banging update  build 42. The blessed relationship with the modding community between players, developers and creators mixing and blending up a dream that I would consider is not a micro-dose. Just started to get the grasp of how to operate the modding system and made a world that runs beautifully on kings-mouth it is open to everyone. I hope everyone has the experience they have been waiting for on this game. I have one last say, I really love the feeling of the settings to customize how we want our apocalypse makes it very unique and forces me to learn more of the game to get a better result every time making these hours endless and helps me find peace in times where i'd rather my mind race on zomboid rather than unwanted thoughts. Thanks for the last 500 hours and here is to many more gonna use a bourbon and jiggas green fire mod to celebrate before horde night comes over. Good day everyone

I would recommend. In this game death is inevitable. Your Game saves are a persistent world that you can build upon each run meaning you will be able to prepare yourself and try to be better next time. When you die, you can kill your old character to get your loot back. Your base will still be there, also. I would play with easy settings your first run to get a feel for it. 

Worth it at full price.

I've played this game for nearly 650 hours, and I can confidently say that I love Project Zomboid with most of, if not all of my heart.
I'm one of those people who fiends for large-scale management games such as Cities: Skylines and Rimworld, but I also love realism, and Project Zomboid is the embodiment of that. This game is probably the most accurate representation of a zombie apocalypse in the real world, and the only way it ends is through your own negligence ending up in death. And the modding community, man. I can play this game vanilla and completely modded and have an amazing and unique experience every time.
To close out, Project Zomboid is definitely worth the cost because of the infinite customization options within it and the amount of time you can find yourself immersed in the apocalypse. I love this game.

been looking at this game for awhile and it has looked interesting. so I watched several how to, tips, best builds and start vids for it before buying.  Tried playing and def think a lot of people would say ... this is how i died  "the funky movement system". The w key being an "up" key instead of forward and the s key being a "down" key instead of backwards is archaic and was when the game was created I can't even remember the last game I played with it.  Using the left/right keys in conjunction with the up/down doesn't actually move you the way it should. I could probably get used to it after many many hours of play but since if u play 2 hrs u can't get a refund I stopped after running the tutorial and just trying 2 starts (the first house was surrounded by zombies even though I was in the build mode). I might give it a try again sometime in the future when I have the patience to unlearn the ingrained movement learned though years of MMO's but cant recommend it right now.

I have continued to watch numerous how to videos and still think I will give it a try again when I have the time to try and unlearn years of normal game movement However one of the vids I recently saw had an item discovered that I realized it was the first time I had ever seen someone score that item.  the lack of the item in every house clearly shows the developers have no clue of the basics of life in the USA .... since the devs website says they are in London not having this item in every house would be like setting the Knox event in the UK and no houses have any...... tea.... What is the item you say ..... well you can find peanut butter, mayo, jelly, butter, cheese galore and tons of Beef but to change up a well known Wendy's commercial

"Wheres the Bread"

Not only would bread get you to stretch many of the above food products but just think of the noodle happiness bonuses from a nice grilled cheese sandwich.

Another item that shows the devs lack of knowledge is TV .... in 1993 when the Knox event takes place it should be noted that "At the start of 1993, 98 percent of American households owned at least one TV set, with 64 percent owning two or more" yet you will find house after house in game w/o a TV.

Not only that, inner logic of most of the game mechanics is quite intuitive and follows the logic of the real world, which allows you to find out new ways of dealing with stuff without looking guides on youtube and such. Downsides so far are quite specific. There is no endgoal, once you have set up the way of supplying yourself with everything you need you can keep living in that state for quite a long time without needing to leave your shelter. There are no other survivors (so far) to have some fight for resources but that could be solved by joining some hardcore public server. Online side of things is good, mods are amazing. Great game.

The compelling aspects of Project Zomboid:

Immersive Survival Experience: Project Zomboid doesn't just simulate survival; it plunges you headfirst into a world where every decision is a matter of life and death. From scrounging for supplies in abandoned buildings to fending off hordes of ravenous zombies, the game immerses you in the gritty reality of a zombie apocalypse like no other.

Complex Character Development: In Project Zomboid, you're not just playing a nameless survivor ‚Äì you're shaping the fate of a unique character with their strengths, weaknesses, and personal backstory. As you progress, you'll have the opportunity to develop skills and abilities that reflect your character's experiences and choices, allowing for deep customization and role-playing possibilities.

Rich Narrative and Atmosphere: Beyond its gameplay mechanics, Project Zomboid excels at crafting a rich narrative and immersive atmosphere that draws you into its world from the moment you start playing. From the eerie silence of deserted streets to the haunting echoes of distant moans, every aspect of the game's environment contributes to its sense of dread and tension.

Strategic Survival Gameplay: Surviving in Project Zomboid isn't just about brute force ‚Äì it's about strategy, resource management, and careful planning. Whether you're barricading yourself in a safe house, scavenging for supplies in the ruins of civilization, or quietly sneaking past undead hordes, every decision you make has consequences that can mean the difference between life and death.

Community and Modding Support: Project Zomboid boasts a vibrant and passionate community of players who contribute to its ongoing success through mods, maps, and other user-generated content. From custom scenarios and challenges to new gameplay mechanics and features, the game's modding scene adds endless replayability and variety to an already rich gaming experience.

Endless Replayability: With its procedurally generated world, dynamic events, and open-ended gameplay, Project Zomboid offers virtually limitless replayability. Whether you're exploring new strategies, testing your survival skills in multiplayer mode, or simply enjoying the thrill of starting anew in a fresh playthrough, the game keeps you coming back for more, time and time again.

In summary, Project Zomboid isn't just a game ‚Äì it's a gripping and immersive journey into the heart of survival horror, where every moment is a struggle for survival and every choice shapes your destiny. With its depth, complexity, and unwavering dedication to authenticity, Project Zomboid stands as a shining example of what a survival game can and should be. So grab your axe, watch your back, and prepare to face the undead ‚Äì in Project Zomboid, the apocalypse is just the beginning of your story.

It takes a minute to get used to the basics and learn the game mechanics but once you've got that down this game is a ton of fun.

Will try to summarize:
-For someone new to game there will be a learning curve... you die a lot in the beginning but once you learn the mechanics and create your own tactics to battle the horde and survive it becomes very fun.
-Developer updates does take a while, but the massive selection of mods makes the game very interesting and does fill in features that the game is currently missing.
-Best to play with other people (as there are no NPC yet), join a friendly pve server if your new, most players are very helpful getting you up to speed. You can join a faction/team to explore, loot resources, secure a base or build it from ground up, rescue other players on the HUGE map, grow food, fish and craft stuff.
-Game is not FPS point of view, its good for those gamer's with motion sickness issue with FPS.

Just like a baby, I wake up without any fatigue or stress in the morning.
I was told there were no issues at my last check-up. I‚Äôm trying to explain that I‚Äôm a person who wishes to live a very quiet life. I played a little when it first came out out, and then spent a little bit of time on the sidelines because of issues with 4K screens. But this has been resolved now.

After letting pot brew, so to speak, Project Zomboid has grown into a beautifully in-depth game that you'll likely not see in any other game. Whilst many games will allow you to "weave your own story", PZ does this in such a unique and punishing way. I've never played a game before where my every decision can sometimes mean the difference between life an death. What you eat, what you wear, where you go, how you get there and what you do all lead into a narrative of your vs nature vs zombies. Eat the wrong food, enter the wrong building and your game could be doomed. You traits add strengths and weakness, but your decisions are ultimate the key to survival. Whilst the zombies might be the threat, bad decision making is ultimately what will kill you. 

Cook your food, forage during the day and never never try to fight off 10 zombies with an umbrella.

Hace m√°s de dos d√©cadas, el mundo fue sumido en el caos debido a un brote de zombis. Los muertos caminaban entre los vivos, y la sociedad colaps√≥ en cuesti√≥n de semanas. T√∫, un superviviente valiente, te encontrabas en la ciudad de Muldraugh, tratando desesperadamente de mantenerte con vida en medio del apocalipsis zombi.

Tu refugio era una modesta casa en las afueras de la ciudad, donde hab√≠as logrado fortificar las ventanas y las puertas lo mejor que pudiste. Los d√≠as se suced√≠an en una rutina interminable de b√∫squeda de suministros, enfrentamientos con zombis y noches ansiosas esperando que el amanecer trajera un poco de seguridad moment√°nea.

Un d√≠a, mientras explorabas una tienda abandonada en busca de comida, encontraste un diario entre los restos de la civilizaci√≥n perdida. Al hojear sus p√°ginas, te diste cuenta de que era tu diario personal de hace m√°s de 20 a√±os. Las palabras escritas a mano te recordaban los momentos antes del brote zombi, las personas que hab√≠as perdido y los sacrificios que hab√≠as hecho para sobrevivir.

La revelaci√≥n fue abrumadora. Te diste cuenta de que el diario estaba lleno de recuerdos que hab√≠as olvidado, eventos traum√°ticos que hab√≠an quedado enterrados en lo m√°s profundo de tu mente para protegerte de la tristeza abrumadora. Con l√°grimas en los ojos, continuaste leyendo, y descubriste que, seg√∫n las √∫ltimas p√°ginas, hab√≠as decidido regresar a tu hogar original para enfrentar tu destino.

Siguiendo las pistas dejadas en tu propio diario, regresaste a la casa donde una vez viviste antes del brote. La estructura estaba desgastada, las tablas en las ventanas ahora eran viejas y carcomidas. Al entrar, el hedor inconfundible del deterioro llenaba el aire. Entre los escombros y los restos de muebles desmoronados, encontraste una puerta cerrada con fuerza.

Con temor en el coraz√≥n, abriste la puerta y te encontraste contigo mismo, pero no en el estado que recordabas. Yac√≠as en una cama, los huesos y la piel descompuestos, vestido con la ropa que llevabas cuando todo se desmoron√≥. Era tu cad√°ver, una versi√≥n de ti mismo que nunca esperaste encontrar.

La tristeza te envolvi√≥ mientras enfrentabas la realidad de tu propio destino. Hab√≠as vuelto a casa para descubrir que la √∫ltima p√°gina de tu diario no contaba con detalle c√≥mo morir√≠as. Sentiste una mezcla de nostalgia y angustia al ver tu propio cad√°ver, recordando los momentos felices que una vez viviste en esa casa antes de que el mundo se sumiera en la oscuridad.

Te quedaste all√≠, en silencio, lamentando lo que una vez fuiste y lo que hab√≠as perdido. El juego de Project Zomboid hab√≠a conservado no solo la lucha por la supervivencia, sino tambi√©n la tragedia personal de encontrarte cara a cara con tu propio final.

BUT I finally gave it a go, and all those prejudices vanished in 2h, and I got freaking addict.

You just forget about all those weird things as soon as you start understanding the fundamentals of the game, it all makes sense, it's all balanced, and what doesn't make sense to you most likely has a mod to fix it.
The dedication of the developers and of the community is beautiful.

i died

When it comes to zombies games this has got to be one of the best out there! 

I wrote a review about 7 Days to Die saying that the reason I love that game is because I like to daydream about what I would do if the shit hit the fan, looking at stores and places and thinking "yeah I could reinforce that wall, put some crop plots there" and this game does exactly that!  

With the ability to create a character and to do almost what you would be able to do in the real world, this game takes it up to the next level when it comes to immersion.  Sneaking around zombies, luring them into a garage with an egg timer and then slamming the garage door shut so you can loot the house.  Breaking into an ambulance and turning the siren on to attract a horde from a building you wanna loot.  The list goes on and on.

With some game/server settings you can turn off loot and zombie re-spawn meaning EVERYTHING in the game will be finite and the the dead stay dead.

Long story short, if you want a simulation of the end of the world. Buy this game!

This game may have a small amount of content overall (about a couple hours to get the full hang of the game and its mechanics), but it goes a long way. Even if you are tired of the base game, Project Zomboid has workshop support, meaning your 20 or so dollars goes a long way with how much content is in the workshop. If you are not motivated to play the game because you are scared or just bored, try listening to music or playing a video to keep your spirits up. If you have a second monitor, even better. If you find yourself getting ambushed because you cannot hear well due to the aforementioned music or video, install the mod that adds a visual sound system around your character. (Mizz made me do this)

Legit the best zombie apocalypse experience in gaming hands down. If you wanted to know how quickly you'd die if everything went to shit, you'll definitely find out (probably in less than 10 min lol). My longest surviving character lived for 10 days post outbreak and I have over 120 hours logged. 

The systems are incredibly in depth and the game is under constant development so things are always being added or improved. The love put into this project is just seeping from every crevice. Also the modding community is incredibly active so there's always great stuff going on in the workshop!

TLDR; 10/10 just buy the game it's so good

I've played exclusively in multiplayer so I can only comment on that. I love it! You kinda need someone who already knows a bit about the game to get into it but after that it is so fun. It really inspired a lot of teamwork. For someone who really doesn't like horror games, this is the perfect amount of tense to still enjoy the game. The risks are perfectly balanced with the rewards. We did download quite a few mods to allow some quality of life things and to flesh out the bits we really liked such as the cooking and the mechanics. Would recommend to anyone wanting a fun challenge and who like playing with friends.

OH NO

Are you tired of the same old zombie games where you mindlessly mow down hordes of the undead? Enter Project Zomboid, where survival means more than just finding the biggest gun.

In Project Zomboid, you'll learn valuable life skills like foraging for food, crafting makeshift weapons, and running for your life like there's no tomorrow - because, well, there might not be. Forget about fancy superpowers; your main superpower here is not becoming a zombie's next meal.

The game's tagline should be "Expect the Unexpected." Just when you think you've found a safe place to rest, a zombie horde crashes your party. And let's not even get started on the joys of accidentally setting yourself on fire while cooking a meal. It's the little surprises that keep you on your toes, right?

If you think surviving alone is tough, try teaming up with friends. Suddenly, your survival strategy goes from "sneak around quietly" to "who can make the most noise and attract the most zombies?" It's like a sitcom, but with more groaning and less laughter.

Project Zomboid is a refreshing take on the zombie apocalypse genre. It's equal parts challenging and hilarious, and it'll make you rethink your zombie survival plan (you did have one, right?). So, grab your baseball bat, stock up on canned beans, and get ready to laugh, cry, and possibly scream a little, because the undead are coming, and they're not here for a friendly chat.

over 2000 hours in and this has slowly worked its way up the rankings as my favorite game of all time.  I'll play other stuff, but Project Zomboid is a game that always calls me back for more. There's so much to learn and so much you can do yet nothing you have to do other than try your best to not die. As a new player, you'll cling on to what you've gathered or built and pout when you inevitably lose it all and go back to square one. You'll call BS when you die and try to blame it on something other than your own mistakes. Then you'll start over, get better, last longer and die again. When you start to love how little this game cares about how special you think your character is and blame yourself for dying... it's just so good

I spawn in with my friend, we look at the map... my friend says he is at mauldraug or whatever the name is, i see his house, i slowly approach it, there is an insane amount of zombies right next to his house, i run, the zombies are knocking, we run. we find about 20 garages, we clear it out, no zombies. we do a garage sale, i get a pair of socks for all garages to be open, i open them with a crowbar, we go the police station, get guns, i see a car. i break into it........ IT HAD AN ALARM, i hotwire the car... it has gas. my friend ran away to the garages, i go there with the car that still has the alarm running, the whole town is upon us..... they break through the gate instantly and start pouring in, we start shooting, a day or two of just straight shooting... they stop coming... i turn on the sirens... i need more blood..... more come.... once again shooting.. after all that... i come close to the corpses. and instantly get sick from how many corpses are there and nearly die to it, we left the location, we found warehouses, we settled, we survived, we thrived.... we wanted to expand..... we went into the forest..... i hear ripping... i ask my friend what it was... he said nothing... i notice a rip in his shirt.... didnt think anything about it. we are fighting more hordes.... and suddenly... he dies.... and turns into a zombie, as he is lying on the ground recovering.. i shoot him in the head.... and then get eaten. 11/10. best game i have ever played. want to replay the exact scenario (this is a real story)
