Alright, serious talk about this game. I dislike that it remains hidden behind the defense of Early Access, but that's not -entirely- the developer's fault. Devs are still updating regularly and I commend them for that. Steam doesn't have a classification for 'Perpetual Development'. I don't think Early Access is the solution. The game is 'done' enough to be released. I don't think waiting for the devs to pass away is a good measure of when to end Early Access.

Zomboid basically a super-granule version of The Sims with zombies. Is the game worth playing? Yes. Is it difficult with a steep learning curve? Yeah, fine. You know you were signing up for that, so whatever.

Okay, so why the downvote?

There's an 'Extra Credits' Youtube episode (back when it was good) called "Depth vs Complexity", which outlines design philosophy of how many working parts a game has (complexity) versus how those mechanics meaningfully affect your gameplay (depth). I'm introducing third variable into this equation that I'll name "Elegance", or how accessible the mechanics are to meaningfully affect your gameplay. Elegance often ends up being the effective ratio of Complexity/Depth; complex, inelegant games stop being accessible, and thus player engagement falls off as the granularity turns into a hamster wheel/skinner box.

Example: In this game, it has dropdown menus over canned food items that allows you to open the cans, but what actually happens the game will search your vicinity for a nearby can opener, then place the can in your inventory so you can handle it, pick it up, open the can, and the place the can opener BACK where you got so you don't lug it around needlessly. This is an elegant mechanic! It has a lot of working mechanics unseen to the player, which we we ultimately don't care about; we wanted the damn can opened. Now it's open, and the interaction felt natural (and elegant), although the can should probably say "needs a can opener." to make things even more straightforward.

-This game is complex. Maybe not Europa Universalus, but complex.
-This game is also... fairly deep. It's no Terraria, but it has multiple levels of divergent strategy and progress breakpoints (when you game progress allows you to access enough returns to move forward.
-This game is NOT elegant on the whole. I spend too much time looking at wikis for basic mechanics. 

As I age, I find myself less and less concerned about complexity and more concerned with depth+elegance. my frail hands strain under the burden of needless, repetitive clicks. I'm running out of them, and eventually I will have none left; such is life. How I spend those clicks is important to me. This game may is working its way towards elegance, but its lacking enough that I'm not enthusiastic to give it an upvote.

I think the biggest issues is that there's a lack of design talent. No offense, Devs, but you haven't figure out how to combine resting with sitting on a couch while reading a book. You can't burn broken stick weapons. dozens of simple item interactions such as attaching a utensil to a stick have been listed crafting recipes, needlessly cluttering the crafting panels. Most of these item interactions could be relegated to tooltips. The foraging panel could be consolidated into a single button/keystroke that looks like an eye, instead we get a clunky panel that takes up precious screen space, where screen space is the bread and butter required to navigate the game's extremely punitive "get bit once and die" premise. There's thousands of these itemized issues that makes a player go "WTF were they thinking?" The entire experience doesn't feel "lived in". It sometimes get glimpses of it, but it doesn't happen often enough. I feel like large portions of this could be addressed simply by slowing down the passage of time, but the devs seem insistent that walking down the street take an hour.

It's honestly kinda laughable sometimes. It seems like this game was built to do a bunch of very specific simulation things, and focus on granularity has caused the devs to, ya know, forget they were developing a game? Or maybe they don't know how, small development teams sometimes get caught up in their own design habits; it's easy to get lost in programming weeds.

Why is the systemic functions of this game so stilted and messy? We have games with very elegant crafting system. How did the devs take so few lessons from games like Valheim, Subnautica, Terraria, Stardew? Hell, STATE OF DECAY. This game is close! It's SO close!

Devs, take a BEAT. In EVERY ACTION a player takes! What is IMPORTANT?

Better yet, what's fun? The game is relatively lifeless in content; it lacks a soul. I know the devs axed story mode and maybe they had good reasons for that (I didn't play it), but this game would be so much more interesting with NPCs, factions, trade hubs. This game seems to have a strict adherence for zombie apocalypse realism, but has completely neglected that statement is an oxymoron. I spend more time acting as a doordash deliverer than I do exploring the world, and for the most part, there's not that much to discover. Game-reward-player-who-good-at-find/manage-junk-with-more-junk.

And NO, don't tell me to go download mods, make a GAME. Take a queue from Neo Scavenger and it's living world. Shouldn't I find "The Lab" or "the Lair?" shouldn't I have events that exceed an annoying helicopter (who's sole purpose is to wreck my first run)? I hope someday they add something like that, because as it is currently, the game forces you to either be enamored with it indefinitely or part on bad terms. When I die, I just feel shitty and like I've wasted my time. In my opinion, that's myopic in scope, if not a flat-out design mistake.

That all being said, they've pulled in top modders as Dev, and that's actually super good faith (and rare) development. But devs, please! Stop relying on modders to make your game make sense. Work on making an interface that feels as natural as a player intent. When given the choice between more options and clear options, choose the latter. Only expand the features of your game if elegance is the result of that added complexity. Push those features towards game content, rather than a perfectly simulated 1990 earth. If you're worried about them being disruptive to your current pacing, place these events far away from spawn zones so players can engage with them on their own terms.

Lastly (less importantly because mods can get around it), the developers have insistent that this game be played in ironman mode only. I can't condone this. The era of accessibility only through 'git good' in a f***ing single player game, a BUILDER no less, is silly. The game has an auto-save feature, you the player are just not allowed to control it. Is losing a 60-hour playthrough to an RNG sounding like fun to you? No? Then don't buy this game.

Devs, all you have to do is make ironman mode optional. Do that, this becomes an upvote. The only people who think that this bad design choice is 'better content' are elitist a**holes, and the rest are lost sales. I'm okay with you losing sales over this. Let us play the damn game the way we want (there is a mod where you can save your character but not your game. I don't consider this to be a comparable implementation to an ironman option).

To prospective buyers: If the above statement DOESN'T bug you, the game is ready to go and worth your time. You can modify the game liberally to your playstyle. The first 12 hours of play is going to be you tearing your hair out. It's supposed to be like that. Read some guides and try again. You'll get it.

A game that has outstanding mod support whilst not relying on it, like so many other games, since its release all the way back in 2013, Indie stone have put their dicks to the grindstone and put out an update on their... well updates, almost every single week! Keeping the player-base informed with weekly updates on how their next major update is coming along is a wonderful thing and more developers should do it.

The gameplay is a teeny bit clunky, BUT that's kinda inevitable with any isometric mouse+keyboard game. Using a controller for movement+combat and using the mouse for going through menus works best!

Final note: do not play this game with the expectation of "winning" there is no ending, the undead hordes (who are fully customizeable i might add!) will eventually rip you to shreds, its just a matter of how long you can hold out. through my many playthroughs, ive lasted anywhere between 2 minutes and 8 hours(8 in game days)

Final Rating
Gameplay 9/10
Soundtrack/Sound Design Shit my pants/10
Graphics 4/10(Can't really get too worked up over it since this is a very small team)
Legitimate feeling of helplessness and Sheer horror 10/10

Overall a solid 8/10 and very much worth your 20$ (13.39 now ACT FAST!)

Project Zomboid is an absolute blast and a masterclass in how to do a survival game right. The first thing that hits you is just how detailed and immersive the world feels. You're thrown into Knox County with nothing but your wits to survive the zombie apocalypse, and boy, does it get intense. Every little choice feels like it has weight, from deciding whether to raid a nearby house for supplies to figuring out if you should rest now or push on a little further.

The game's realism is something else. You have to manage everything - hunger, sleep, even your character's mental health. It's not just about killing zombies; it's about surviving in the truest sense. Need to eat? Better learn to forage or farm. Got a wound? Hope you've found some medical supplies or know basic first aid. It's this depth that makes every playthrough feel unique and thrilling.

Crafting and base-building are a whole other level of fun. You can barricade yourself in an existing building, or if you're feeling ambitious, start building your own fortress from scratch. The sense of achievement when you've set up a safe, functional base is unmatched. And let's not forget the zombies. They're not your typical dumb, slow-moving horde. They're unpredictable, and the game's AI ensures that you can never let your guard down. One moment you're scavenging in peace, the next you're sprinting for your life because you made too much noise.

The game also has a dynamic weather system and a day-night cycle that affects gameplay. Rain can mask your noise, making it easier to move stealthily, but it can also lead to illness if you're not careful. The cycle of day and night affects visibility and zombie behavior, adding another layer to the already complex strategy of survival.

But what truly makes "Project Zomboid" stand out is the community and the developers' engagement with it. The game has been shaped and improved over time with feedback from players, and the mod support is fantastic. The community has created mods that add everything from new items and mechanics to entirely new maps.

In short, "Project Zomboid" is an incredible survival game that challenges you in ways few other games do. It's not just about making it through the night or killing zombies; it's about creating a sustainable way of life in a world that's out to get you. With its deep gameplay mechanics, challenging realism, and supportive community, it's a game that keeps you coming back for more, eager to face whatever it throws at you next. Whether you're a die-hard fan of survival games or someone looking for a deep, engaging gaming experience, "Project Zomboid" is a must-play.

[h2]The Best Zombie Experience[/h2]

This has to be one of my favorite games of all time, the way you can create a character and slowly build that character both physically and mentally for months in game is something i don‚Äôt think any other game can recreate. The learning curve is sharper than any game I've ever played, this game [b]will[/b] challenge you in ways you cant imagine. [h1] Best Zombie Survival Game [/h1] 
Project Zomboid is an open-world isometric survival horror video game in development by British and Canadian independent developer The Indie Stone. The game is set in a post-apocalyptic, zombie-infested world in the 1990s where the player is challenged to survive for as long as possible before inevitably dying.
 
[table]
    [tr]
        [th]About[/th]
        [th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üíæGraphics[/td]
        [td]The graphics are really unique for a survival game (well for me). A top down view really got me hesitant on buying it, but I deeply enjoyed it! It plays so well in this perspective. The graphics are pretty good too. It will age really well in the future. Not much to say in the graphics department. It has an indie vibe and I like it. The graphics are pleasant and have amazing lighting with more improvements in the future.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üéÆGameplay[/td]
        [td]I played many zombie survival games in my time, but none felt as real as project zomboid. There are no special infected like Left 4 Dead, there is no action packed story, and the world is based in a real location. Basically you make your own story. How would you survive the end of the world? This game captures that pretty well. You start off by creating your own character. There are positive and negative traits you can pick to make your character feel truly unique. It‚Äôs an incredible system that works perfectly for this game. You can farm in this game, you can be a cop that has amazing shooting skills and bravery. You can basically role play this game. There are some flaws though. For example base building needs an overhaul. There is not much you can do in terms of building. You can design your place really well, and add a ton of character to it. But like you can‚Äôt make rooftops, or watch towers for example. The base building needs a lot of work. The foundation is there, but I feel like they can do so much more in this area (which I‚Äôm sure they will in later updates). So your best bet is to find an existing house or building and build up on that with the limited tool they provide at the moment. There are no NPCs or animals yet, but they are currently working on them which is amazing news. This is the Dark Souls of survival games in my opinion. Winter is cruel to you, in the later stages it can get really challenging as food spoils and water and power shuts off. The zombies are challenging as well. One bit will end you, and if you are unlucky a laceration from a zombie or scratch can even infect you. Be careful out there if you play this and don‚Äôt underestimate the dead.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üé≠Multiplayer[/td]
        [td]The multiplayer runs so well and is super easy to get going. You can have many players on your server as well. The more RAM you have, the better it will run so just be cautious. I never stress tested the player count. I had up to 5 players and had no problem with my setup. You can make a server with 100+ mods and as long as they have the mods too, I had zero issues with it in my 400+ hours on this game (mostly on multiplayer).[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üïõPlaytime[/td]
        [td]This game has a high play time. I don‚Äôt really get into survival games and I put around 500 hours into this game. The modding community makes this game breathe. This is such a hardcore survival and sometimes can feel really relaxing. The playstyles are infinite. You can make your own story and get so immersed. If you have friends that always wanted a zombie survival game that actually felt realistic, you will put so much time here![/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üéßSound[/td]
        [td]Sound is so important in this game. Turn off the music (I personally hate it), and just immerse yourself into the world. Audio is so well done in this game. You have to pay attention to the zombies and hear where they may be, all from the bushes, branches being snapped, alarms going off, etc. If you don‚Äôt pay attention, you will get bit and die. Also your own audio is important. Be careful of alarms of watches, car alarms, house alarms, etc. They can be deadly. You can shout if needed to distract the zombies to save your friend, or even shoot a gun to distract them. Guns can even be a lifesaver and life ender (if that‚Äôs a word). Guns can bring in so many zombies. The sound design is just so in depth and incredible, and so well designed.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]‚ùóBugs‚ùó[/td]
        [td]The multiplayer can be a little buggy. The driving can be glitchy at high speeds at the moment. Luckily the devs are facing a lot of multiplayer issues (since the multiplayer is kinda new to the game). Besides that I haven‚Äôt really noticed any major bugs on my playthroughs. Just the driving can be kinda buggy at times.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üîÖPerformance[/td]
        [td]The optimization is pretty good but it still can use some work I feel. Luckily the developers are already on that. The animations are pretty good and the lighting is really impressive! One bad thing is the lag in multiplayer while driving. Now they are on a fix for this but just thought I‚Äôd let you know about it. It‚Äôs not game breaking, just annoying especially with the stutters at high speeds. [/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]‚úîÔ∏èPro‚Äôs[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Mod Support
[*]Tons of freedom
[*]Multiplayer support
[*]Trait and skill system
[*]Amazing community
[*]Huge attention to detail
[*]Immersive survival experience
[*]Amazing role playing capability
[*]Extensive crafting and building system
[*]Realistic zombie survival experience
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]‚ùåCon‚Äôs[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Early Access for over 10 years
[*]Updates take a while to release
[*]Driving is laggy on multiplayer at times
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üèÜRating[/td]
        [td]9.5/10
This game is worth full price. It‚Äôs a survival gem and they deserve the support.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üîóConclusion[/td]
        [td]Project Zomboid has a Walking Dead vibe to it (I thought I‚Äôd never say that about a game). It captures a zombie apocalypse so well. I don‚Äôt really get into survival games, but this one really got me hooked. The modding community is absolutely insane. You can see the passion behind this game, and I don‚Äôt see it slowing down anytime soon.[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

Firstly id like to say that this game went above and beyond my expectations.
It is highly immersive, has a very real and compelling zombie narrative which can be further improved with mods of course that not only change the way the game can be played but it has a especially given the game a fresh take with the quality of life content it provides.

Secondly it is a super hardcore experience even if sandbox settings are tweaked to be easier, Because of the perma-Death you feel like every action has consequences like in real life.
even after my 200 plus hours ive still been learning new things/mechanics in the game.
I have died many times but recently my play styles have changed and id have to say that the base building is satisfying.
Literally any item can be placed in the world that is picked up to make bases etc really feel alive and at home for your character.

Thirdly Death in the game is only the beginning......For example you can pick up from where you left off as a new character with the draw back being that you lose all skills acquired from your previous character.
If you liked to be highly immersed in a Zombie apocalypse then this is the game for you.
If you want to hate life and yourself tweak settings in sand box to give the desired out come but with that said i recommend playing the game first in its intended way so you can truly appreciate the progression of your character and most of all yourself as the player.

Lastly its like you are the director of a movie and your character is the protagonist thats destined to die, even from over confidents or from becoming to complacent.
i could go on and on about the pros and cons but as it stands the many pros of this game is overpowering in comparison to the cons so i cant recommend this game enough.
with the Multiplayer its another story though, id definitely play with some friends or join the many communities available.
its the most awful thing to see your best friends or your character whos been alive for over a week if you make it that far die from turning in to the undead then having to either kill or run from them.

 (PS) Using the betas sections on the game will give you a bunch of different game versions.If i was you playing on the build 41_78_7 is the way to go, well at least until the build 42 comes out anyway.

Mods keep this game very alive. However, I cannot go over some very serious issues that the devs seem to not want to go over.


*PUSHING ANIMATION GOES THROUGH ZOMBIES.
*ZOIDS SPAWN RIGHT OUTSIDE YOUR HOUSE, NOT EVEN 10M AWAY; (I've had this even with respawning off)
*ATROCIOUS SOUND ATTRACTING ZOMBIES.
*IF YOU MISS HITTING DOWN A ZOID, BE SURE THAT HIS CRAWL ATTACK WILL PUSH YOU DOWN. THEN YOU WILL GET STUNCLOCK.
(because when you get attacked by someone on the back you don't have the intuition to simply run, but to wait for the animation to stop and then run; VERY VERY REALISTIC)
*YOUR GUN SHOT LITERALLY CAN HIT A ZOMBIE AND DO 0 DAMAGE.
*YOUR GUN SHOT WILL DO LESS DAMAGE IF YOU ARE DAMAGED ON YOUR HAND
(because bullet speed are affected by the scratch on my hand; VERY REALISTIC)
*YOU CAN STAY NEAR A WINDOW AND A CRAWLER JUMPING THROUGH THE WINDOW ATTACKS YOU IN THE OPPOSITE DIRECTION AND STILL HITS YOU.
HIT YOU IN THE FUCKING SHOULDER. WHILE HE IS ON THE GROUND.
*YOU WILL SHOOT POINTBLANK A ZOMBIE RIGHT IN FRONT OF YOU AND YOU WILL STILL MISS WITH A SHOTGUN
*IF A CRAWLER IS TRYING TO BITE YOU AND YOU WALK BEHIND HIM YOU WILL STILL GET BITTEN AND STUNLOCKED BY IT. WHILE YOU ARE BEHIND HIS BITING ANIMATION. (very rery realistic!)
*IF A ZOID JUMPS OVER A FENCE AND THEN CRAWL ATTACKS YOU AND IN FRONT OF HIM IS ANOTHER FENCE, HE WILL STILL ATTACK YOU, EVEN THOUGH THERE IS A SOLID BLOCK THAT SHOULD BLOCK HIS HITBOX!( VERY FUCKING REALISTIC )
*YOU WILL SEE SPRINTERS THAT LITERALLY WALK NORMALLY FOR SECONDS AND THEN TURN YOUR BACK LITERALLY WAKE UP THAT ZOID TURNED INTO A SPRINTER AND BIT YOU FROM THE BACK

The game plays more like a zombie rogue-like with survival crafting elements, rather than a full blown survival crafting game. Except without the permanent upgrades that rogue-like games typically have. So think Rogue Legacy (without the permanent upgrades you get after dying) with zombie themed survival elements. 

My issue is your character has to have weaknesses to balance out their strengths, which you pick at character creation. You might pick them to be better at fitness and melee weapons, but you'll have to counter that with a negative trait, such as slow reader, or something else (you get to pick these). 

I picked slow reader for mine, which makes reading books take longer. When trying to read a book in the game (which is how you level your skills), the little bar didn't move at all. I sat there and waited for a good solid minute. Not even a single dot worth of progress, so I stopped. This feels too punishing - that I basically can't read any books, so I can never advance any skill on this character. Not without sitting and waiting for who knows how long, anyway. But it's going to take so long, it's essentially become useless to try.

With some of these things essentially locked out for your character, that's a part of the game you won't get to experience. At least not for that "run". While that's fine, I guess, if that's the style of game you're going for, I simply don't enjoy that style of game play in survival crafting games. To me, the point of survival crafting games are to slowly build your character & base up over time. Not constantly start a new run every couple of days.

Don't get me wrong, I enjoy rogue-like games from time to time, but I usually know what to expect going into it. I didn't expect that with Project Zomboid, however. And, I think it could work as a rogue-like, if it just implemented permanent upgrades like most other rogue-likes.

But I just can't recommend this game, because the game play mechanics don't match the genre (in my opinion). Still, some might enjoy these things, I just personally do not. If I want to play a rogue-like, I will play a rogue-like. If I want to play a zombie survival crafting game, I will play something else.

Only 200 hours in, but the time really flies by playing this game.

Still in early access and the Dev team rolls out updates at a snails' pace, but the quality of content is good and the depth of the game will really keep you invested.

I also play DayZ, which is a PvP game (with survival elements), but I wanted a solid Solo zombie survival game and this one scratches the itch perfectly.

Don't let the isometric 3D graphics put you off, the depth of this experience is excellent and will keep you invested for many, many hours of freedom and exploration.

The number 1 killer in this game is complacency... one bite and it can be all over.

Very good mod support, very active community.  You can tailor your zombie survival experience exactly how you want it to be and the game progresses through the seasons over time.

A great game with many more hours to come, I can strongly recommend Project Zomboid to anyone who loves survival games that are solo friendly.

Can't want to see more updates for this game from the developer who's still active and rolling out the free updates and content additions!

I've played Zomboid across many accounts and have racked up a serious amount of hours. 
Unfortunately I'm still warning most players to not put any money into this game for how the development team has put off core mechanics (promised years ago,) and the still fractured state of online connectivity. You know, when you can't physically drive faster than 30? Or your lag gets you killed because zombies ignore base game settings and grab/lunge/hold you through walls. 
This game SHOULD be fantastic but it has SO FAR to go. 
It's been so long though, that this fan is just about done. 
P.S The Discord mods will also ban you if you point out any of these issues in their Discord, BUYER BEWARE.

Update 2023: Game still horribly buggy and zero updates have come out to address it. Only the promise of VISUALS...?
Also, they will BAN you from the community chat for calling any of this out in forums, again buyer beware!
Update: 01/2024: Booted up for some checkin' out- zero updates (it's now been years,)  all previous connectivity issues and visual bugs are still very present. Funny update, all discussion updates are locked with zero comments by mods for how many people call out the lack up updates. Sucks to suck.

this is a tough recommend. I love and hate this game. I'm definitely going to continue playing it, no questions about that. but this game is not a mindless romp. it's tough and you have to figure out a game plan, whether playing alone or with friends.

at a certain point, every setting is adjustable. number of zombies, amount of food, when electricity and water shut off and how far into the apocalypse you are (also lots and lots of mods). figure out what is survivable and go from there. don't discourage yourself with iron man runs right off the bat.

Original review posted at 12 hours of playtime.

Hi, yes, I got past the helicopter, yes I survived the power and water turning off, yes I used cars and guns, yes I went to the wikis, and subreddits, and no I haven't played with mods or multiplayer.

This is all from the solo experience in survival, builder, and sandbox modes. Mods don't come installed with 
the vanilla game, so I don't care about how much better they make the game.

That being said...

This is probably the most frustrating sim game that has ever existed. People will praise it for its "realistic" and "innovative" mechanics, its "subtle" story-telling and addictive gameplay loop...when in actuality it just means putting a loading bar on every single action in the game and having you watch your character slowly, or quickly die . 

Drink water: loading bar.
Eat food: loading bar.
Use item: loading bar. 
Move item: loading bar. 
Grab item from inside a bag: Loading bar to unpack the item, and another loading bar to equip the item. 

Was it a gun that you were grabbing from inside your backpack?

Well, I hope earlier in the day you went through the 20 individually segmented loading bars to load the mag, then went through the additional loading bar to insert the mag into the gun, and then put the gun on your back, because now you have to do 21 individual loading bars to get through while a mob of zombies spawns on top of your character even though you just came from the very same direction and nothing was there.

And even if all these actions were instant, it still wouldn't make this Sims 3 version of 7 Days to Die more enjoyable.

You spawn in, and the zombies are immediately on you.

Need weapons?

Gotta fight 10 Zombies bare handed.

Exhausted?

Enjoy going from 2 hits to kill a zombie - to 8. Against a horde of 10+.

Decided not to fight and run instead?

Enjoy aggroing every zombie that was in a home because apparently zombies get to grow eyes all over their heads, and sneaking means nothing!

Need protective gear?

Most veteran player will tell you "just don't take damage" as if that's actual advice to be taken seriously in anything other than a bullet-hell. But you can still get what you can, just don't catch heat stroke from all the layers you're wearing.

Got a scratch or got bitten anyways because a fucking ninja zombie spawned out of nowhere with no visual or auditory indication whatsoever?

Congratulations, you may now a dead man walking. Have fun finding out in the next 3 days (Unless you got bit THEN YOU'RE 100% FUCKED LOL HAHAHA XDDDDDDzZzzZzzz.)

Why?

Because the devs want zombification to 100% be the reason you die! It's not enough to just get overwhelmed by the infinite hordes that come after you DAY AND NIGHT while you're exploring, who cares that you have an entire system based around injuries where massive chunks of health are removed from the various devastating concussions, mangled limbs, and hemorrhaging lacerations no, no,NO... ANY contact with the dead runs the risk of infecting you. Sure they have an ENTIRE SYSTEM DEDICATED TO TREATING PLAYER WOUNDS, but FUCK IT! DIE YOU DUMMY! LOL! YOU GOT SCRATCHED ON YOUR LEFT PINKY 3 DAYS AGO!!!! OOOOOPS!!!!!

 So have fun making DOZENS of characters that KEEP dying because... who would ACTUALLY want to explore the massive map we made in a SANDBOX? Right? YOU DON'T ACTUALLY WANT TO DEVELOP YOUR CHARACTER WITH RPG MECHANICS IN OUR GAME DID YOU???? TOOOO BAAAAAAAAAAD!!!!!

And don't tell me that this is all for the sake of the realism, or the atmosphere, this kind of bs isn't part of any story, or to keep experiences fresh, it's for the purpose of being a massive waste time.

I'm not gonna give any leeway to a game on its "realism" if I can't even sit in a chair while I read a book or watch tv. Let alone not being able to do both at the same time.

Editor's Note (@ 33hrs.): I have now played with some help from a friend I made while streaming a new playthrough of the game. Thank you EN for teaching me about all the inventory management tips, moodle advice, skill progression help, and for explaining all the little obscure quality of life features that I would have never figured out on my own! I still really think that this game would benefit form an advanced tutorial, or even having multiple tutorials that explain all the features that are in the game. There are countless people that all have some variation of "I have been playing for around 100+ hours and never knew that you could (insert feature that is never explained here)". 

Maybe one day the thumb will flip over.

I have played this game in many ways, up and down, left to right, solo and multiplayer, "roleplay" or fuckarounds, did probably everything possible and it still is capable of throwing new things at me.
The whole spirit of "This is how you died" shows what Zomboid is all about. You are not winning. The best thing that may happen is you don't die. There is one goal; Survive, as long as possible, if possible.
And with that comes the only bad thing about this game: over time i've seen more and more of my friends getting bored by surviving as they found their own playstyle, wich worked. Worked too well, so they didn't care about surviving anymore as it was "too easy". The challenge to make goals, reach something etc. has vanished and with that the reason to play on did too.
One way to encourage to keep playing, is to set goals, step by step, and write them down, so you have something "physically" reminding you whats milestones you can get, and already got.
With that in mind, I am looking forward to Build 42, as i think the new systems will help smoothen out the endgame curve a little.
Right now, the game is one of my favourites. Especially with mods its replayability is near infinite, with friends, the possibilites are infinite. 
The Sandbox makes the game the way you want it to be, with all its settings, you can learn the game, and create scenarios as you wish.
About the game itself, i don't care about the graphics. Zomboid does a unspeakable great job in detail work, the clouds in the sky, the reflection in the car windows, the sounds and the games OST, the different systems (Now, Foraging, Health, and especially the moodles; Later, probably fishing as well), they all make the game as beautifull as it is.
Nothing will ever top the feeling of playing in a group, while listening to some chill tunes, and working in or on a base and just enjoying the game.
Combining Zomboid and a good friend group increases its potential exponentially as everything is hilarious, when your friend mistakes a tree for your buddy who's already in the car.

Pro's:
- Supports many playstyles
- Many mods
- Easy multiplayer (without the need of dedicated servers)
- Sandbox mode
- Detailed systems
- Teaching the basics

Con's:
- Multiplayer (servers behaving funny sometimes)
- Endgame state is boring/repetitive
- Pretty hard for beginners to pick up

All in all, this game is a 9,4/10.

Fuck yeah I recommend this, it's pretty much my favourite game.  I think it's [i]the[/i] zombie apocalypse survival sim.  Others seem to lean toward arcade or pvp-looter-builder-shooter.

It's got all the hallmarks of a survival semi-rpg.
[list]
[*] Character traits, skills, customisation.
[*] Looting, crafting, building, farming.
[*] A whole bunch of melee and ranged weapons.
[*] An interesting take on free-form cooking.
[*] Somewhat realistic world and "survival" mechanics like health, medical, environment, weather, seasons.
[/list]

Expansive modding potential and community.  There's a shit-ton of mods for all sorts of things.

It's been in development a long time.  But it's in [b]active[/b] development, which is important.  So it's just a matter of time for certain features - but how long is too long to wait?

Other good things in my opinion:
[list]
[*] No arbitrary time-based tower-defence-like hordes or waves in the "normal" game mode.  There's challenge maps for some of that kind of gameplay, as well as mods.  Instead, if a horde is after you, it's because they were attracted and not because it's day 7 or something and that's the game.

[*] No "special" zombies spitting acid or throwing cars.  Just regular shuffling (or sprinting) zombies.  The danger comes in the fact that there's fucking heaps of them, and it doesn't take much to take you out of the game.
[/list]

But it's not without flaws.
[*] [b]As of this[/b], it has no NPCs.  Single-player is kind of "lonely".  Except NPCs have always been on the cards and will be coming in future builds - it's just a matter of time.

[*] It's a sandbox in that in-game objectives are not explicit or specific.  It's basically "try not to die", or maybe "die in a magnificent fashion".  Whatever you set out to do is up to you, but not backed by anything in-game.

[*] [b]As of this[/b], end-game is arguably non-existent.  Despite the game telling you "There was no hope of survival, this is how you died"; once you know what you're doing and are equipped, have a vehicle, a base, whatever, you've kind of beaten it.  You [i]have[/i] survived.  Boredom probably ends the game for you at that point, unless maybe you decide then to set out to clear towns and kill every zombie, sooner or later getting bitten.  The developers have plans to address end-game so we'll see.

[*] The UX/UI will not be to everyone's taste.

[*] The level of detail/complexity to some aspects won't be to everyone's taste.  E.g. managing ammo for a gun with a magazine: Open a box of ammo; eject a magazine; insert rounds in the magazine; insert magazine again and rack/reload.  Some things have had QOL treatment, some things could do with it.  Considering the outlined ideas around crafting/building/end-game, detail and complexity may be the direction the game is going in.

I've spent more than quite a few hours on this game, however, depending on what you care about, Project Zomboid may not be for you. Although I believe it's wonderfully crafted, the one glaring flaw is by far the lack of a goal or end-game state for which to aim. Without speaking at length, if you're not a fan of games without a clear-cut story, or even general sandbox end-game goal, like Minecraft, then I wouldn't consider this something worth your time. Certainly, if you get bored often with those types of games, I would stay clear.

Notwithstanding that fact, a great group of friends, and a few mods, can make the experience much more enduring, as despite being a single-player lover, I've always found that my friends and I can naturally form a goal. This modding community's love and passion for the game, along with the support from the developers for that passion, will keep this game going long after it's completed.

By far, this is the greatest zombie survival game that I've ever played - add NPCs and quests (it doesn't have to be a main story), and it could be the greatest survival game ever made. Until then, consider my comments to figure out if it's for you.

after 50+ hours, I've learned a few things: 

First, don't get too attached to a character. The opening screen warns us and I've come to realize the truth of the statement: This is how you die. I've died to groups of Zs. I've died of infection. I've died from a single bite after being distracted IRL. Death is a constant companion in this game, and it's just a matter of time before your medical professional meets the same fate as her patients.

Second, take it slow. sure you can rush through, load up on weapons and go on a killing spree, but you miss out on what makes this game unique: the characters themselves. your lumberjack shouldn't be shoving ice cream in his face through the visor of a motorcycle helmet. taking the time to remove gear when you get home from a zombie killing and looting spree gives your characters life.

Third and finally, while this game is fun solo, it's even more so with friends. I just started playing with my sister's fiance, and having someone to watch your back and talk to throughout the zombie apocalypse adds just the right amount of additional hope to suck you in further. 

The modding community is top notch, adding quality of life improvements and just an insane amount of additional vehicles, gear, and even special zombies. there's something special about finally being able to move the furniture without having to break it down, or even just being able to see the corpses you move, or the generator you pick up.

TLDR; this game is fantastic and I recommend you give it a shot.

I downloaded the game during a sale, a week after the release of build 41. I played it for maybe 2 hours, lost about 5 different characters and decided that I hated it. It wasn't until I had came back a month later after watching a few videos about the game. I booted up zomboid with a few select mods that I had also heard were good. 

My character was Alfonzo Fulhmer. Alfonzo stayed inside of his starter house for a week. He was a underweight, keen hearing fast learner. He was a carpenter before the outbreak. He learnt alot about the world he was living in while looking out his dust stained windows. A few more days went by as i sent Alfonzo out to his neighbor's houses to collect food and necessities. I didn't know what to grab so I made him haul everything. Down to each red dinner plate and blue pen. My house was boarded up, window curtains drawn and Alfonzo sat alone in his home. In the small town of rosewood was where he resided. his quaint little home in a world of chaos. He lived a boring life, Alfonzo grew depressed and each action he took seemed like a lifetime. (I didn't know how to speed up time) I had sent Alfonzo on a trip further then he had gone before. To get to the gas station. I wanted him to get a car so that future adventures wouldn't be so difficult.

The helicopter came 12 days after he had been sculpted from the character creator screen. He was outside walking down alleys and side roads when he heard the low rumbling of the news helicopter. Alfonzo sprinted home hoping that he would be fast enough to hide. He thought he was safe until the unending waves of the undead surrounded his small bungalow. He sat alone in his bathroom hoping for them to leave but the helicopter continued to circle. The banging grew louder as the dead had broken into his home. He stayed silent but no avail. the wave pushed past each other and barreled towards the door Alfonzo was hiding behind. He died alone in agony, I sat watching hopeless and desperate for the help that hadn't come. Alfonzo was dead and what remains of him wanders the streets of Rosewood.

Hello fellow gamers, 


Im going to tell you my adventure playing Project Zomboid.  I want to say first off I love the idea of playing a game in the open world full of zombies.  You can do a ton of little things from bandaging your wounds to deconstructing furniture.  The difficullty in the game is what kind of scared me but then i kind of understood why.  It was to catch the interest of players getting addicted to the game to play one more day.  

Now here are some of  the things i didn't like about the game.  The tutorial was bad and it  basicallly put you to your death at the end of it and you  don't learn from it and you just die.  In the tutorial, I was tasked to press a few buttons but i had no explanation on all the classes you could play in the game like trying to be a carpenter or a farmer or a cook or a trapper and so on.  The items were kind of clunky too because you want to get things in and out of your inventory as much as possible, so i could drop certain amount of items on the ground and not all of them.

Now for the ugly part of the game, i almost don't want to talk about it because it was so bad.  The community of this multiplayer game is horrendously toxic.  I am a complete new player to the game and I'm trying to seek ways to get help. almost no one has the patience to help me from the beginning to the end without being chill about it.  I went on discord and YouTube to try to learn the game but it turns out all of them are jerks who want to play their game their own little way.  The players say I can play  on my own and learn on my own but the game by design is easier with more people so i try to at least play with one other person.  The first duo partner i had to play long term basically summarized as this ;we weren't meant to play together because i got mad at all the little things and blocked me on discord; and the person said we should never play with eachother again and that person recommended that i should be able to find someone else to play with on a day to day basis who will teach me the game. To be honest, this is what turned me away from the game because I know nothing about the game and the next person  will be the same problem and i noticed the players on discord weren't getting along with others for this reason or another, so why would they help me.  If you are trying to reach out to people in this game, you won't get far and so now I am rating this a thumbs down for me for the experience that i had to go through in this game as a newbie to the game.

I played Baulder's Gate 3 in their discord and I tried to find a long term player to play with and everything went well between us until something came up. that something was his girl friend complaining about how he was spending so much time playing with me, so I stopped messaging him because i felt bad about the situation of doing the things we planned on doing together.  Baulder's Gate 3 has the same problem as this game but not as bad as this game is in multiplayer mode.

To fix the community problem,   I would simply say put up chat windows in the game for things that a new player would be looking for. For example, You can go to a new to the game chat box  or  just a chat and chill box  or join these servers if you're new to the game.

This game sucks. No learning curve, hard as it gets to understand what is basically happening around you, plus it doesn't matter what you do, the game will ALWAYS set the odds and enemies on to you at the worst possible moment. There is ALWAYS something that goes magically wrong to leave you helpless. I gave it 2 huge chances, one a long time ago and again now, month or so ago. UNINSTALLED.

I have a long history with this game, and to this day in my 44 years of life, their public forum is the only place I have ever been banned from, and that was for pointing out their glacial development cycle, which now holds the Steam record for being in early access the longest, so its hard to think I was wrong when they are setting Steam records. Anyhow I am running this game on top end hardware in 2024 (4090 etc) and the game still has serious optimization issues and countless bugs that break everything (it is well known that  the engine is a spaghetti coded amateur pile of rancid filth, and I run with an extensive suite of community mods just to make this game tolerable). The game is coded in LUA which is now 31 years old and not meant to support a game with this much intended depth. This is an ugly janky game with some charm and a very dedicated fan base, but outside of that a ton of development issues hold this game back in numerous ways and even the most positive content creators are getting fed up with Indie Stone and their lack of ability and embarrassingly slow progress.

God, I wanted to like this game so badly, but it sucks. It honestly might be one of the most boring games I've ever played. It's so slow! Nothing happens most of the time! 

Zombies just absolutely overwhelm just about every single road on the map, which makes playing this game even more dull than it already is - dull because it's predictable. For a game that prides itself on realism, almost every single house or street - even the ones that are rural -  are just filled to the brim with zombies. It doesn't make sense. Why is a country house in the middle of the woods filled with 20 zombies?

The "profession" that you pick at the start makes practically no difference. The perks you pick have no impact. You spawn almost immediately surrounded by 21837192 zombies so every playthrough is exactly the same: spawn, go somewhere rural, and then spend 20-40 minutes trying to find a house in the middle of nowhere, find nothing, restart. 

This game punishes you for trying to do anything even remotely enjoyable. Want to check if this car is broken? Too bad, there's 48919 zombies surrounding it. Want to check this prison for weapons? Too bad, all the doors are locked and there's no way in. Want to check this house for food? No, you get nothing, and here's 12 zombies to chase you out. I get it, it's supposed to be rough, but we shouldn't be just breaking the natural cycle to make the game difficult. If zombies are out here, supposedly looking for food, why are the stood staring at this car in the middle of some rural plain? Why are they camping out in someone rural house bedroom? It doesn't make sense that they'd be surviving like this.

Your character constantly complains about food, sweat, pain etc. He's the most hypochondriac character/person/thing I've ever seen. Slight dampness and he complains like he's being physically tortured. Run for more than 2 seconds and he cries even more. His carrying capacity is 12lbs for some reason, and carrying an extra 1lb makes your legs break. Again, I thought this game was going for realism. I get it, they're game developers, they're not exactly going to be the strongest people, but they do know the average man can lift a decent weight right?

Guns, when you find them, are fun but absolutely useless. The in-game menus are basic, yet convoluted and obnoxiously difficult to use. Bags, or any type of carrying container that isn't the best bag in the world, are just completely pointless. The time it takes to pick them up, and arrange your stuff into it, basically negates the 0%-20% encumbrance bonus you get.

Everything about this game irritates me, can you tell? It just feels like everything I'd want to do in a real world situation, is possible in this game, but only if you're open to accepting some unrealistic "debuff" for it.
It's one of it's kind. I would say Project zomboid is one of the best if not the best zombie game

As much as I anticipate B42, I am happy waiting!

Alright. Im gonna go on a rant about this game. Prepare yourself. 
 
         In Project Zomboid, you have to do more than just fight zombies. You need to eat, drink, and stay healthy. It's like a big puzzle where you have to figure out how to survive each day. This makes the game more exciting because every choice you make matters. It's not just about fighting ‚Äì it's about being smart to stay alive.
         What's really neat is that Project Zomboid lets you create your own story. The game changes based on the choices you make. You can explore different places and face different challenges every time you play. It's like writing your own adventure where you're the hero, yet you're not. At any moment you could be mauled by devious little creatures known as the Zomboids. One bite and your dead.
          The world in Project Zomboid is like a real place. There are cities, countryside, and everything in between. The game pays attention to small details like day turning into night, different weather, and how things decay over time. It feels like a living, breathing world that you get to explore.
         It's not just a game, it changes who you are, and I love Project Zomboid for it.

I've on and off ran a small server for me and a buddy, and occasionally a third person every once in a while. The mod community props up PZ, and PZ in turn employs some of their most passionate modders later by adding them to a growing team of developers.

It's a mutualistic relationship, and while the game isn't in any state I'd say is "complete", given its numerous systems that need overhauls or are complete grind fests (looking at you, electronics skill)... it's definitely got heart. If you can interface with a UI that is painful sometimes, with a learning curve that will have you looking up how to manufacture car parts with metal sheets and a propane torch...

I still recommend a group of friends try this game, you'll be hooting after the group gets swamped with zeds scrounging for a can opener in a neighborhood and siphoning gas with their homies trying to get it back to the hoopty that you found that still had its keys in the glove box. 

9/10, as soon as Build 42 updates the crafting (and by extension, the skills) systems this game will be rejuvenated af.

I gave this game a shot because it looked fun. Its not casual friendly which isnt a problem. But the RNG is annoying. I just looted 4 crowbars in the warehouses south west of Muldraugh (day 3). Everything was running smoothly when the character just decided to stop defending himself against 3 Z. 9 Strength 9 Fitness 2 long blunt, no debufs except depressed. Thats annoying. It might be because I play on streaming service but regardless. If this harmless situation can get you killed like that its just retarded. They should add a savegame feature whenever you sleep. The RNG is just terrible.
I played on Apocalypse in single player.

Its not even a competitive game, so why they completely omitted savegame options is beyond me.

If you dont have a job and look to kill time while also getting frustrated permanently this game is for you. Gameplay is great, unfortunately you will hardly get so see most of the game unless you are willing to put up with its bullshit. I am not. Suit yourselves.

Edit: I did some testing to put some numbers to the review. Starting with nimble 3 (600%xp) + fast learner trait (x1.3xp) 20 points in nimble take you 5 real life minutes of strafing in combat stance. This is the fastest you can get as of 20220210. This means to outpace z in combat stance it takes you 5250 points from there. Which translates to TWENTYTWO (22) REAL LIFE HOURS of you doing nothing but uninterrupted strafing in combat stance. This means if you start your game and you also pick wakeful (-30% sleep required) you spend the first 29 ingame days to get to nimble lvl6 (outpacing z). Of these 29 days you spend 22 strafing and 7 sleeping. If this doesnt sound like a waste of time to you nothing will.

Edit: if you want to know why I added so many played hours since the negative review - I have changed systems and am now able to access the savegames and back them up manually, like everyone else. Fix your game devs.

I was stocked up with food, water, a little beer... A car. I was getting ready to set up my first base.

AND THEN THAT [REDACTED] HELICOPTER! I hate that thing. It showed up, wouldn't [REDACTED] off, and then zombie, after zombie, after zombie. I got pushed away from my car and hit a house to try and escape to heal up when the house alarm went off. And then more zombies. I couldn't...escape... there was no end.

I got grabbed, and bitten, I managed to escape, but it was too late. I was bleeding, heavily. I couldn't find a minute of peace. Just. To. Bandage myself.

Full of atmosphere and challenge - combat isn't exciting but it's just enough to keep you in.  In fact, it's the layering and layering of systems that makes this game tick.  Each one is pretty simple, but their interactions are cool.  You wanted to bake a cake in a burntout wasteland with zombies trying to break in?  You can do that.  You want to run over zombies in a mad dash through the suburbs in a police car with your sirens blaring.  You can do that too.

IDK how many times I've died because of some sort of jank. We lost our best truck and trailer in multiplayer because I desynched into oblivion. Why am I growing radishes and tomatoes which require refrigeration for  storage when dried beans and lentils exist as a food product already? Why aren't I able to grow those? Why is rain water tainted? Why is it magically potable when plumbed from rain barrels to a sink or tub? It's slow doing any significant construction because carrying 5 planks annihilates your body.

I also dislike zombie things. Really. I have never played a zombie game or watched a zombie movie that was particularly interesting to me. Just not my thing.

All that said, Zomboid has quickly become one of my favorite games. However you want to play an apocalyptic zombie survival game is up to you. Want to have tons of loot and focus on infrastructure to survive? Want lots of cars to chop so you can convoy across the city grabbing everything and anything of value? Want to play light and lean and sneak on foot? Want to focus on farming off in the middle of nowhere? Slow dumb hordes? Fast and nasty little groups who won't quit chasing you? It's all up to you. Add ample workshop content to that equation and the world is your oyster.

If this game piques your interest at all, I'd say the only caveat to consider is whether you think a little bit of jank/balance/WIP type situation will bother you at all. If not, I highly recommend it.

Navigating the relentless challenges of Project Zomboid can be painfully exhilarating. The constant threat of zombies, scarcity of resources, and the ever-present fear of permadeath create a tense atmosphere. The feeling of vulnerability intensifies as you struggle to survive, making each decision crucial. The game's unforgiving nature can lead to heart-wrenching moments, where hours of progress can be wiped out by a single mistake or an unexpected zombie horde. Yet, it's precisely this brutal difficulty that makes Project Zomboid a uniquely immersive and, at times, painfully rewarding experience.
Really hard, but very rewarding when you start learning the game

Project zomboid continues a long and un-fun tradition of making games that have no win condition. The borderline illegality of making a game that you literally cannot win should be debatable as cruel or unusual. The game is not fun, combat is slow and unrewarding, guns are completely useless as they just lure in every zombie from 100 yards.

Okay, so there is an extremely steep learning curve and you can become a zombie grinding machine if you pick a specific weapon type. The best traits for this are fast learner and/or the specific occupation that gives a bonus to that type of weapon. Your best bet is to go-for broke right away and look for your weapon. The crowbar is incredibly durable and can become a 1hit-crit machine. Still, you are always only one mistake away from a 10-day death sentence and that looming fact just makes it not fun.

Now, in my few hundred hours of playing Project Zomboid, I've never spent such a abundant time on a game. This game is such a overlooked gem, and such a spectacular community. This game is made for everyone and everything. Want a game to RP? Project Zomboid can do that. Want a hard-core, unforgiving experience? It can do that too. What about building a economy and profiting? Very monopoly man of you, but yes. Want to make friendships and experience heartbreak? Too many times I remember that...  WHO'S CUTTING ONIONS AGAIN? But, Project Zomboid isn't just some plain boring basic game, it's one of the most realistic, intriguing, and expansive in all fields of gaming genres, in one package.  Also, great for single-player and multi-player people alike. So, in my time thriving and surviving, i can very well say that this game is a masterpiece in my book. I also now manage a server of my own for players all alike to join together and cherish the experience! If you do get it, try it with some friends if possible its always better together forever than alone.

Incredible game! The devs have continued development on the game throughout its existence, because they understand that no matter how good something is, it can always be better. They seem to care about the game AND the community. They listen to feedback. Rather than pump out a quick game for a quick buck, they are putting in REAL effort, love, and passion into this game. That means it will still be here long into the next generation of other games. It's a popular genre of zombie survival, except it stays true to the name. It's SURVIVAL, not a zombie shoot-em-up. Insane customization for server settings, to make the experience what you want it to be. There is multiplayer, which is just useful when humans are pretending to not be what they really are, which is just disgustingly selfish, greedy, immoral a**holes. The game doesn't have the best graphics, but that means it can run on nearly ANY computer, even a cheap laptop that isn't really designed for gaming. That means this game is made for ANYBODY who wants to play it. Not just gamers with high-end equipment. It truly is the best game I've ever played. Maybe it will make Game of the Year whenever it is fully released. I think that it should.

"The Game Was Rigged From The Start"

I have a love hate relationship with this game, on one hand it's commitment to realism is admirable and makes it a very challenging game which in my opinion is a good thing ... to an extent. It's commitment to realism almost makes the game unplayable at times. Have you ever wondered what would happen if you were in a zombie apocalypse? You'd die. That's it. Videos on Youtube will portray it as a challenging  yet fun and rewarding playthrough, as if it is a roguelike and things get easier with each new survivor. But that is simply not true, I have sunk a good 20 hours and countless survivors into this game and I feel as though I am getting no better at the game. The game has copious amounts of Bullshit in it like spawning in houses currently infested with zombies. Not being able to grab items left by the survivors of your previous playthroughs. Zombies that always magically know where you are even if your sneaking around, and avoiding there sight lines and above all else a difficulty that makes the game realistic, but one of the most soul crushing annoying games of all time. The only reason I keep going back to it is in a futile attempt to prove the game wrong and say "No, fuck you. I can beat you." But there is no beating project zomboid, I find myself less in a manner of rage quitting and more in a manner of staring at my computer screen as I spawn in a fully infested house, and thinking "I hate this. Why am I spending my freetime on this? On an instant death simulator." Project Zomboid also forces you to do what I like to call virtual chores. Like reading that takes forever to build your skills, that takes far too long. I'm not against this in theory, but the game seems to want you to just stay in your house. Because realistically that's what you would do. But what the fuck is the fun in that? My virtual character is not the only one who is bored by it. But it's more "fun" then dying for instantly. In conclusion if Project Zomboid implemented more balance into the game I think it would be fun, perhaps making the occupations matter a bit more? Or perhaps doing a better job at allowing each death to further overall progress in some way but as is. This game is as dreadful as the apocalypse it presents. Maybe I just need to sink a bit more time into it, but as is, this game has taken an ungodly amount of energy out of me and I absolutely do not recommend this game.

no. just no. my sanity? time? all spent here. Was is worth it? with the people I played with yes. Realistically? no.

Anyway, a good game if you want a slow paced, building, and time consuming survival game. Not great if you get into it too much and spend a lot of time into it, losing time on other priorities like I did.

Gameplay Mechanics:

Project Zomboid's gameplay mechanics are a testament to its commitment to realism and player immersion. The survival elements are finely tuned, demanding strategic thinking and resource management. The day-night cycle, seasons, and weather conditions all play pivotal roles in shaping the gameplay experience.

The game's extensive skill system allows players to customize their characters with a wide range of abilities, from carpentry and cooking to medical skills. Each skill level attained feels like a hard-earned achievement, contributing to the sense of progression and growth within the game. The integration of skills into the overall survival narrative is seamless, making every learned skill a valuable asset in the struggle for survival.

The intricacies of combat in Project Zomboid add a layer of realism seldom seen in other games. Melee combat requires precision and timing, and firearms come with their own set of challenges, including attracting more undead with the noise generated. This attention to detail extends to the damage system, where injuries affect movement and overall capabilities, adding another layer of complexity to survival scenarios.

Narrative Depth:

While Project Zomboid may not have a traditional linear narrative, its emergent storytelling is a marvel. The narrative unfolds dynamically based on player choices, creating unique and personal stories for each player. The abandoned homes, remnants of the world that once was, serve as silent witnesses to the apocalypse, allowing players to piece together the events that led to the current state of affairs.

The absence of a traditional plotline is not a drawback; rather, it enhances the game's replayability as each playthrough brings new challenges and narratives. The interactions with non-playable characters (NPCs) further contribute to the narrative depth. These characters, with their own stories and struggles, add a human element to the post-apocalyptic world, making it feel lived-in and authentic.

Community Impact:

Project Zomboid's community has played a crucial role in its ongoing success. The game's development has been shaped by player feedback, with the developers actively engaging with the community to implement features, address issues, and refine the overall gaming experience. The modding community, in particular, has flourished, creating a plethora of user-generated content that expands and enhances the game in various ways.

The sense of community extends to multiplayer gameplay, where players collaborate or compete in a shared world. The dynamic interactions between players, from forming alliances to engaging in PvP encounters, create a living, breathing ecosystem within the game. This player-driven aspect of Project Zomboid adds an extra layer of unpredictability and excitement to the overall experience.

Technical Aspects:

From a technical standpoint, Project Zomboid stands out for its stability and performance. The isometric perspective, while serving the gameplay, also ensures that the game runs smoothly on a wide range of hardware configurations. The optimization allows players to immerse themselves fully in the post-apocalyptic world without being hindered by technical issues.

Regular updates and patches demonstrate the developers' commitment to refining and polishing the game. The inclusion of new features, improvements, and bug fixes showcases the ongoing dedication to delivering a high-quality gaming experience.

Innovation and Influence:

Project Zomboid's innovative approach to survival gaming has had a notable influence on the gaming industry. It has inspired other developers to explore realistic survival mechanics and emergent storytelling. The game's success as an indie title has demonstrated the viability of niche genres and the importance of player engagement in the development process.

In conclusion, Project Zomboid is more than just a game; it's a dynamic and ever-evolving experience that continues to captivate players. Its commitment to realism, extensive gameplay mechanics, emergent storytelling, community engagement, and technical prowess make it a standout title in the world of indie gaming. As players continue to shape their narratives within the post-apocalyptic sandbox, Project Zomboid remains a testament to the limitless possibilities of immersive gaming experiences. thank you for reading this  review

[I usually play with a decent amount of mods] One of the most in-depth survival sandbox games I have ever played, while also having zombies. Match-made in heaven. As a fan of both genres, having played tons of Minecraft, 7 Days, Valheim, GTA, Mount & Blade, I haven't played a sandbox game that has felt so fleshed out in quite a while. Everywhere I go in this huge world, there is always something to interact with, or something hidden away waiting to be discovered. I do think that your own imagination will take you further than what the game is built for. The game has a very steep learning curve that took me until about 30-40 hours to truly get the hang of the game, and even at 400 I am still learning new ways to develop skills, as well as just getting better clicking & fighting the zombies. Now I like to build fun challenges for myself. Can be riddled with bugs, especially when you load up mods, but I haven't ran into anything that has "ruined" the experience. One of my favorite time-sinks that I've played lately. Haven't had a game like this that I can just binge for hours on end.

After purchasing this game I have now become very aware that a zombie apocalypse is pretty much impossible to survive. I mean according to the lord we are immune to the airborne variant of the Knox infection but not the bite. So even if your one of those people who managed to become immune to the airborne variant. Congrats, you‚Äôre now fighting for survival against endless hordes of undead. Now I understand how the world got overwhelmed in the walking dead. It wasn‚Äôt that the military was weaker than my 80 year old grandma lying on her deathbed, it‚Äôs because the infected have the ability to swarm and overwhelm us. I cannot tell you how many times I‚Äôve died or got bitten in this game due to a horde of only 4 zomboids coming at me in all directions. I also can‚Äôt believe that this game simulates a real life apocalypse, I mean you literally get to listen or watch the news on a radio or tv and learn what‚Äôs happening all around the world and how the government is doing. Not only that, but this game also happens to start you off with the power grid and water supply on, but after the world finally falls to the Knox infection, the power and water shuts off. Leaving you and your best pal the zomboids alone. With no hope of survival and with food running low. All you can wait for is death. And yes, death is imminent and inevitable in this game. I mean after all this game is all about how you died in this apocalypse where all hope was lost and humanity stood no chance against the onslaught of the zomboids who once use to be just like you.

On the outset I want to mention that Project Zomboid does not feel like an early access game.  I've had a lot less bugs than most fully released games and there is a lot of content.

Project Zomboid is what you would expect.  A holdover from the era of one life to live survival crafting with all of the pros and cons that the genre brings with it, made somewhat worse by the fiddly controls, but with more depth than I was expecting.  Just as an example, you have 4 starting maps to choose from, any one of which is large enough to play an entire game out on, except it turns out these starting locations are all part of one giant map and only a tiny portion of the cities and towns and rural areas in the game.

The tie-breaker for me between recommending this or not is how configurable the game is.  There's always a lot of tough decisions to make in game design about different mechanics that are going to appeal to different types of players.  Some people like the grind, some don't.  Some people want a run and gun, some people want to hide and build.  Well this kinda gets around that by giving you tons of customization options if you want to use them.  

The default settings are brutal realism, and realistically, 99.99% of people in a zombie apocalypse are going to die right away, otherwise it wouldn't be an apocalypse.  Realistically, guns are too loud to be practical, building fortifications is also noisy, learning a skill takes months of practice, the game is a lot more about patience, hiding, holing up and waiting for the right time to move.  It's not Left 4 Dead.  Well, unless you want to be.  You can achieve the Left 4 Dead experience by fiddling with the game configuration options the right way.  I definitely learned the appeal of this hyper realistic gamestyle but I still really don't like the grind, so I turned up XP gains, but on the other hand there are some ways to get a bunch of XP early on that I find cheesy, so I just don't use them.  It means I'm a bit behind at the beginning but then the later game doesn't drag as much.  I actually have a few different presets depending on whether I feel like a more ponderous game, or something that's got more of a Don't Starve pacing, or if I just want a run and gun splatfest.  You could even just turn zombies off and play it as a weird "Sims but post-apocalypse" if you wanted.

Especially at the beginning, I would tone down a lot of the brutal realism until you get your sealegs, I've even seen the dev pop into a few threads to mention that.

[h1]Project Zomboid - Found a shotgun, survived for 5 minutes, then attracted the entire neighborhood[/h1]

[h2]Impressions:[/h2]
Welcome to Project Zomboid, where the undead roam, your supplies dwindle faster than your optimism, and survival is about as likely as finding a unicorn in a zombie-infested forest. This game turns the zombie apocalypse into a dark comedy, with your character stumbling through the chaos like a mix between a ninja and a slapstick comedian.

[h2]What I liked:[/h2]
‚óºÔ∏è [b]Realism with a Side of Humor:[/b] Project Zomboid takes the zombie survival genre to a whole new level of realism. From crafting makeshift weapons to scavenging for canned beans, every action feels like a desperate bid for survival. Yet, the game manages to inject humor into the bleakness, turning even the direst situations into moments of absurdity.
‚óºÔ∏è [b]Dynamic World:[/b] The world of Project Zomboid evolves in real-time, and it doesn't care if you're ready for it. Seasons change, electricity fails, and your favorite safehouse might just become the next zombie hot spot. The dynamic nature of the world keeps you on your toes, ensuring that boredom is a luxury you can't afford.
‚óºÔ∏è [b]Character Customization:[/b] Forget about playing as a generic survivor; Project Zomboid lets you create a character with quirks, traits, and skills. Whether you're a master chef with a talent for carpentry or an unlucky soul who's allergic to pretty much everything, the customization adds a layer of personality to your struggle for survival.

[h2]What I didn't like:[/h2]
‚óºÔ∏è [b]Steep Learning Curve:[/b] Surviving in Project Zomboid is no cakewalk, and the learning curve is steeper than a mountain of zombie corpses. From managing your character's needs to navigating the intricacies of crafting, expect a few (hundred) deaths before you become a seasoned apocalypse pro. Trial, error, and zombie bites are your teachers.
‚óºÔ∏è [b]Graphics That Won't Win Awards:[/b] If you're expecting cutting-edge graphics that could rival Hollywood CGI, you're in for a disappointment. Project Zomboid's visuals are more retro than a disco ball at a zombie prom. The charm lies in the gameplay, not the eye candy.
‚óºÔ∏è [b]Solo Can Feel Lonely:[/b] While the game supports multiplayer, solo survival can sometimes feel like a lonely affair. The absence of human interaction, especially in a world overrun by the undead, can make you yearn for a virtual companion or two. Zombies are great and all, but a chat now and then wouldn't hurt.

[h2]Conclusion:[/h2]
Project Zomboid isn't just a game; it's a hilarious descent into the madness of survival. Its realistic mechanics, dynamic world, and character customization make it a gem in the zombie apocalypse genre. Yes, the learning curve is steep, the graphics are more retro than a '90s sitcom, and solo play can feel a bit desolate. However, if you're ready to embrace the chaos, laugh in the face of impending doom, and die a few (hundred) times, Project Zomboid is the zombie-filled sandbox where your survival story unfolds like a tragicomedy in the ruins of civilization. Grab your canned beans and nail-studded baseball bat ‚Äì it's zombie hunting time!

Despite its minimal almost "Sims 1" style graphics. Project Zomboid remains one of the most immersive games I've ever played. At times, I was so immersed in the world, that I would enter a similar mindset to my character. No game, (Other than Celeste) has done that for me. Combine Project Zomboids simplicity with its in-depth mechanics, and you got a game that is easy to pick up, but hard to put down. Not to mention the atmosphere of abandoned 1990s Kentucky, it looks normal for the first few days, but everything is off. Doors left open, houses barricaded, food left on countertops. Not to mention watching it all decay and get silent in real time, which is again improved by its amazing sound design. You jump at every window scrape, every off rhythm knock. After a few days, the only sound is you and the horde surrounding you. Speaking of sound, Project Zomboid has many "Events" that happen, such as gunshots in the distance, screams, and news choppers following you around, bringing the undead closer. (If you like those events, check out expanded helicopter events!) The dev team is also quite responsive and active, informing players about updates and things happening in the community via blog-like posts. The game is also incredibly easy to mod, with many mods adjusting major things, such as adding more cars, guns, mechanics, or even cities to visit!

TLDR: Project Zomboid is amazing, very immersive, good mod support, gave me depression.

P.S: Don't play without true music, trust me, the silence sucks.

So, this is a little complicated product.

It is there over 10 years. The graphics side is not the top notch one and there is practically zero story to follow at the first sight.

On the other hand. Graphics fits and you will not take it account after a while. It is fully up to you what the story will be. The very basic premise is there: there is no chance to survival, this is story about you and how you died.

You will try to survive for a day, week, month... and you will die most stupid ways you can imagine. Are you too loud and aggro too many, hungry, zombies? Set up your generator inside and suffocate because its exhausts? Starvation, dehydration, laceration, malnutrition, poisoning, exploding microwave, falling from highrise, real life fatigue, infection from untended wounds, cold weather, hot weather, fever... 

And then, you will find yourself surviving for x-th month in a row, with so nicely fortified base, with loads of food, self sufficient farm and sustainable source of water only to die again on something totally stupid. 

Please not, one can get bored playing single player after a while, especially if you are not RolePlaying type of player who could set his own game-goals. But there is also multiplayer where whole game gets absolutely different feeling. Plus there are some mods. And I mean SOME (a lot) mods you will subscribe to and after a while you will almost forget that they are not part of vanilla game. Ten, fifty and even maybe hundreds of mods available around can modify your experience and give you much more what you can do in this game.

Sure, Project Zomboid have its flaws, it is far from ideal, a lot of stuff is unfinished and without mods it can feel a bit empty, but it is a great zombie themed game. 

(at the time of this review 230+ hours in, playing 16x population, hardest possible settings living on outskirts of Raven Creek with mods wrapped around Hydrocraft while waiting for update 42)
