This game scratched the itch I didn't even know I had. 
While there are pros and cons to this game still being in active development, the strong modding community makes up for whatever the game lacks, and that isn't much. The game offers several game modes and challenges with a sandbox feature that lets you adjust just about every aspect of the game. Would you like your zeds to be slow moving husks that you can one shot? You got it. Would you rather they be juggernaut sprinters that instakill you? Done. Is there not enough resources to scavenge? Maybe you think there's actually too much to find and things should be more scarce. You can change that too.
With friends, the chaos can be a lot of fun. There's nothing quite like hurriedly trying to exit a building full of zeds only to trip over your buddy and be devoured. The seeds of distrust that sow themselves when one of your party is injured and you can no longer trust that he isn't infected and could turn at any moment.
I'd highly recommend giving this game a shot. Spawn, survive, die. Spawn again, survive longer, die again. Repeat. I love it. So much in fact, that I actually took the time to write my first ever review for a game.

Oh, you thought you were playing a survival game? Oh, oh no. This is how you died. 

As a huge zombie nerd, Project Zomboid has taken over my limited gaming time as of late.

Is it the leading contender for realistic graphics? No. However, it‚Äôs design gives you exactly what you need to enjoy your experience. It‚Äôs not busy, everything you see (and don‚Äôt) is essential. The audio is a big aspect as well. You can only let out a little yelp when a zombie jump scares you through a window so many times before you question how tough you really are.

A few aspects I really enjoy that I feel add to the experience is:
- You can‚Äôt tell the time until you scavenge a watch, either in a house or on a body
- The weather has lasting effects. Strip down if you‚Äôre planning on running in the sun, wouldn‚Äôt want to overheat and slow down‚Ä¶ Stay in the rain too long and you might catch a cold. Make sure you have tissue on you if this is the case‚Ä¶
- Your characters past matters! Were they a Ranger before the apocalypse? Perfect, you‚Äôre much better at traversing the trees and foraging for useful treasures. Were they a criminal? That‚Äôs cool too! Now you‚Äôre able to hot wire vehicles and proficiently sneak past those pesky undead.
- Strategy is the name of the game. If you plan on keeping a save for a while, you‚Äôre best to keep away from those bodies, even if they‚Äôre crawling through the windows. The skills you develop matter, so I suggest reading a carpentry book or two, and getting some wood over that opening‚Ä¶

The crafting system is intuitive, you‚Äôve got no shortage of options for weapons and base building, shoot, make a starry and have some cake if you‚Äôre feeling up to it! However, it takes a while of playing, dying, and messing around to get the hang of it. If you‚Äôre impatient or unwilling to adapt, you‚Äôll struggle big time. 

The support of the community is still pretty strong, the devs are still constantly in communication and releasing content, fixes, etc. 

Even if you‚Äôre not big on mods, here‚Äôs a list of one‚Äôs I find elevate your experience:
- Better Sorting by ChobitsCrazy
- Rugged Recipes by Afterworlds
- Gun Stock Attack: Remaster by SportXAI
- Map Symbol Size Slider by capsgry
- Draw On The Map - Free Hand Drawing by Notloc
- M-13‚Äôs Reading Tweaks by General M-13
- Moar Can Openers by NoctisFalco

Anyway, TLDR, play the game!

Made a game with my friends, here is how it went:

-I started as a criminal
-stole a car
-picked up a friend
-looted the gas station
-broke into a police station
-got a shotgun, and a pistol
-friend got guns
-another friend joins the game
-first friend starts building houses
-me and 2nd go and loot a gun store, I get a magnum.
-1st friend gets bit randomly, I put him down with the shotgun
-he was mad, so he claimed the shop across the street, claiming he was a "goblin"
-he almost killed friend 2, when he went to check on him
-the "goblin" makes some pipebombs, and now only wears a hazmat suit.
-Me, and some others team to kill the goblin, a suprise attack
-it is succesfull, but friend 2 is injured.
-out of fear, me and everyone leave rosewood, to escape the goblin.
-we build a town, out in the woods. 
-we manage to make peace with the goblin, because i gave him 50 bottles of bourbon.
-due to a zombie respawn issue, the whole town of rosewood was overrun very badly.
-town was destroyed by a horde
-me and the goblin team to kill many zombies
-our car breaks down at the town
-we flee on foot, me using a shotgun, him a DB
-he runs out of ammo first, choosing to use a pistol next
-i run out of ammo, so i pull the magnum from earlier.
-I kill lots, but the magnum runs out.
-I pull out a machete, from a looting run
-I rip and tear lots
-the goblin runs out of pistol ammo, and uses a baseball bat.
-soon, there are too many, so we are forced to flee through the forest
-we get surronded, the goblin dies first.
-I get surrounded, and mauled to death

10/10 would team with the goblin again

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand‚Äîthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed‚Äîthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Ah, Project Zomboid, the game that turned me from a regular gamer into a virtual apocalypse survivor!

Despite the undead delights of Project Zomboid, there are a couple of stumbling blocks in this otherwise flawless apocalypse. First and foremost, attempting to configure a multiplayer dedicated server is like trying to decipher a treasure map written in a language only zombies understand. The process could use a serious injection of user-friendliness. I find myself grappling with server settings more than I do with the undead, longing for a smoother experience when trying to enjoy the game with my fellow survivors. A little less server configuration frustration would undoubtedly go a long way in enhancing the multiplayer escapades. Secondly... still no human NPCs!

On the sunnier side of the apocalypse, Project Zomboid stands tall as one of the gaming gems that has won my undead heart. It's not just a game; it's my digital haven in the midst of chaos. From the constant thrill of survival to the joy of crafting and customization, each moment is a testament to the game's ability to turn the grim into the amusing. In a world overrun by zombies, who knew building your own fortress could be so satisfying?

The addictiveness of Project Zomboid is almost unfair. Time flies faster than my in-game character sprinting from a hungry horde, and the game's relentless pursuit of fun keeps me hooked. Multiplayer mode adds a delightful twist, turning the survival roller coaster into a team effort. Crafting in this game is an art form, and the customization options are a post-apocalyptic dream come true. The development team deserves a virtual high-five for their continuous efforts in keeping the game fresh, and the modding community adds a layer of customization that feels like Christmas morning in the apocalypse. Project Zomboid isn't just a game; it's a digital playground for those who find joy in surviving, thriving, and occasionally fending off zombies with a crafted, spiked baseball bat. It's a journey I willingly embark on, knowing that my next undead encounter is just around the corner, waiting to test my survival skills once again.

I love this game so much, but it is absolutely unplayable. Ever since I upgraded to a 17in laptop, the UI scaling is so broken that I literally cannot read the font in the game. I've been having this issue for over a year, and a quick Google search of this problem can prove that this has been a long time issue that the developers seem to not care about. What is weird is that this game used to work on my smaller screened laptop, but now is ridiculous. I've tried everything to fix it - every forum response or tip to fix this I have tried. Nothing works.

I absolutely do NOT recommend this game until they fix this UI scaling issue. This game is coming off of my computer until it's fixed.

>Spawn in a gun owner's house
>Get a pistol with 1 full round
>Plenty of canned goods
>No can opener
>Journey from house to house for a can opener
>Found a house full of canned goods, 2 guns and plenty of ammunition
>Found a can opener
>At this point I have a lot of stuff, it's very heavy
>Kidnapper Van outside the current house, perfect for hauling stuff
>Found the Car Keys and went to a nice clearing on the beach away from the streets through the forest
>Not much gas to go anywhere, this is home now
>Have enough canned goods to last a while here, plus the beach as a source for seawater that can be boiled
>All that is left is to find a way to make food and clear out nearby roaming zombies and I'm set
>Only problem is that I'm kind of exposed out here, aside from the van. I'd be done for if, for instance, something got the zombies' attention over here and I had a hoard. The van has no gas left, I'm just using the heating now. Good thing this game doesn't have an event like that happen haha

Update: 5 days later an event happened, and I not only had to leave the van I had to leave the entire area. I walked for at least a mile until I found a cabin. I stayed there a while until I ran out of food. I go outside to find that roaming zombies are even all the way out here. I go from house to house, staying as long as I can until food runs out, each time I feel a little more sickly until finally, in an upperclass neighborhood, I feel so sick that I know I won't survive. I give up, jumping out the two-story window. Turns out I got sick from a cut that got infected. Always wash your cuts.

Absolutely love this game. Gives you a real sense of living in a classical zombie apocalypse. You can make your own choices with the difficult prospect of surviving. And not just against the zombies, you need to keep track of everything. Food, Water, Shelter, Keeping Warm, Avoiding Depression, Etc. This is the most amount of effort put into a game on the daily living requirements a person requires, and it's still early access. That's right, the game isn't finished but there is already so much to do. The map is gigantic! And everything was placed down individually by the developers in this map. And they are constantly adding to it and new features and everything. As for an end game, there isn't one yet (see above of "early access") but it's a sandbox. You can make your own end game for yourself, or with friends as this even allows multiplayer. It's a small team so updates are few and far between, but I'm going to keep my eye on how this game develops.

The main conclusion I get from playing this game is 'less is more'. I'm not a fan of micromanaging abstract concepts like temperature, specific injury locations, fear effects, etc. My biggest criticism is that hunger is far too punishing for what it is; you get hungry far too quickly, and thus your entire goal comes down to finding food. This will continue to be a problem unless you are fortunate to start farming early, and farming is somewhat clunky. Scavenging, while greatly improved from its initial state, isn't very reliable unless you're willing to spend a great deal of time leveling it up. Even then, knowing exactly 'where' to scavenge is still an art; not a science.

My updated review!

You start out, go outside, die. You start out, look around your house, try to fight a zombie, die. Find a crappy weapon, scuffle with some zombies, get bit, die. You find a weapon, and some food. you learn the ropes a bit, walk out of your house, try to hot wire a car, die. Do this again, die. For about 30 hours of playtime, you are stuck in a loop of surviving for maybe a few days, and dying. Thought you would be the main character in a zombie armageddon? Maybe after 180,452,745,44.26 something deaths.

Some pros I personally love about the game is the amount of stuff you can interact with, and change. About the whole world, you can just rip apart and build something new on top of, but zombies can and will destroy it when they find you. One thing Im extremely fascinated with is that there is not a singular house or area you cannot enter. Every door has a room. A special design, different tools, different intricate stories. Zombies, that by themselves are easily killable, but when they clump up, theres a chance you will be torn apart. You do not instantly turn, leaving you 2-3 days to find out what to do, maybe drive to louisville, do some sightseeing? Use your remaining strength to scavenge without much risk, because your pretty much dead already? Or you can run into a herd, and end it in a painful way for your character. Or, lock yourself in a room, and chug bleach  till you eventually die. Then, you make a new character. With its own talents, appearence, house, etc. You go and find your old body, pick all of its stuff up, and continue. You may die several times, and then, you will get a character that you will stick with, and survive for the rest of your playthrough. You can build an "inpenetrable" fortress, but when you hear those helicopter blades whirring in the sky, say your prayers, because every zombie in louisville, rosewood, west point, and riverside heard that, and they WILL come for you. Once you survive it, you will be done. You are left with the task of living out your days, with the constant passive threat of zombies. Welp, thats it!



































Personally, I love the customizaion and general detail in this game. There are many ups and downs to this game, and one i see on these reviews the most is repetitive gameplay. There is not much of an objective once you have a base, just sit and wait to die. NPC's would be a great upgrade, or objectives. The game is very easy to get rich on, but theres a lot of road blocks. Firstly, its a steep learning curve. I never quite get to the long term stage out of pure boredom. The games great, but I never get a character over a month life-span. If your first starting out, I strongly reccomend sandbox or builder mode and learn the ropes. Then, when it gets boring, add mods! I stopped at 67 hours of playtime due to boredom, and now im at 113 hours. Mods at  a bit more meaning to the game.

A Girl's Ode to Project Zomboid

In the world of Kentucky, she embarked with glee, A girl with a passion for survival, wild and free. For 2,000 hours, she roamed the undead land, Embracing Project Zomboid, her heart in its command.

Survival Mechanics Hunger and thirst, her constant foes, Yet she braved the trials, as the hunger grows. Managing her character's every need, In this virtual world, where her spirit was freed.

Base Building Fortifying walls, a fortress she raised, A shelter from chaos, where her soul blazed. Traps and defenses, against the zombie horde, In this virtual haven, her strength soared.

Exploration Through houses and stores, she dared to roam, In search of supplies, she made her home. Venturing into the unknown, her spirit unbound, Project Zomboid's world, her playground.

Character Customization Choosing her path, traits and skills in hand, A reflection of herself, in this digital land. Professions and abilities, shaping her fate, In Project Zomboid's world, she felt truly great.

Cooperative Gameplay Alone or with friends, she faced the night, In cooperative struggles, her heart took flight. United against darkness, they stood side by side, In this virtual realm, her spirit couldn't hide.

Realistic Survival Simulation Injuries and illness, a challenge to face, A mirror of life, in this virtual space. Taking precautions, her resilience shone bright, As she fought for survival, day and night.

Permadeath A risk she embraced, in the face of despair, Persevering through loss, with a heart laid bare. Starting anew, as the journey unfolds, In this digital world, her story it holds.

this game is by far one of the most advanced zombie survival games i have ever seen or played. the game might look boring at first glance but as soon as you get to playing the game it is incredibly fun and addictive. i can play this game for hours on end and still be having fun.

This game is a fucking masterpiece. However, this game is based off of micromanagement with a control scheme akin to that of total war (Considering the amount of individual controls there are for different actions). This game is not about winning so don't get mad when you die. Yes, this game has some bugs, but in my over 300 hour playtime, the few I have encountered have mostly been because of mods. The game is not finished yet. The dev team is quite small so major updates are few and far between. There is no end goal (yet) aside from the ones you decide to put upon yourself. This game is a realism survival sim with an emphasis on properly managing the resources at your disposal. Mistakes can be made that WILL end your playthrough. The game is not about making you happy, it is about making you struggle. In spite of all of the perceived flaws i have previously mention in the review, I cannot recommend this game more (Partially because of the masochistic pleasure you get from building you character then losing all you progress). This game has numerous features that I have never seen in any other game. The modding community is one of the best communities on steam (imo) simular to that of rimworld. The game focuses itself on you to make you struggle to survive and the main focus of the game is getting yourself out of sticky situations. IF YOU DO NOT TAKE RISKS IN THIS GAME YOU WILL NOT HAVE FUN. Leaving negative reviews under this game is ignorant if you have under 100 hours (I have 300 and still have new experiences in this game every time I play). So overall, if this doesn't sound like something you would like, go play something else. P.S.  If you are feeling bored of your playthrough of PZ I highly recommend a mod called 10 years later. <3

I enjoyed this game, but I can't recommend it as of now.

It's been almost 13 years (march 2011) since the development began, and 10 years since it was first released on Steam, and it really doesn't feel like it.

People have been waiting for more than 2 years for the next build (namely build 42), and it does not feel like it's gonna be released in the next week, as we don't even have an ETA.

No NPCs (build 43... I'll die of old age before I see it released), no hunting... Imagine buying an Early Access game to support development, only to discover that it's gonna be your kids who will enjoy the finished game (if it ever gets finished).

The game (allegedly) generated 108 million dollars in 10 years (that's 10 millions per year, mind you), it makes sense that they make it last as long as they can... At the expense of players who HAVE to rely on the modders to get a more acceptable game to play with.

I have had this game since like forever, and it doesn't feel like any progress has been made (it has, but it's eminently negligible given the enormous time span), and I feel scammed.

So, no, I cannot recommend buying this game until NPCs and quests and things like that have been added to the game, and it probably won't be until year 2027 or something.

Decided to give this a try while searching for a singleplayer game which is not overly competitive so I can relax. Personally I find this game very good, because you can really get immersed into the zombie apocalypse theme. The game itself has some ''problems'' which can be annoying but many quality of life mods fix these and it's pretty easy to install them and use them so game feels less complicated at times.

I am currently loving the game and the online community on most servers I tried are really nice, it's one of those games where you can relax but then still get your heart racing because you misjudged the situation and get totally owned by zombies. The game itself is not easy, has a decent learning curve but when you get a hang of it, which you can really fast if you search around on youtube for guides you will have a lot of fun. If you have friends that can play with you I can see sinking at least 500+ hours.

For the price it is WELL WORTH IT in my opinion.

This game is a cross between The Sims and DayZ. Putting the player in the highly engaging role of survivor during a zombie apocalypse, offering tons of experience through environmental storytelling. You can choose your character build to craft a variety of narratives for role playing. 
The multi-player has some hiccups, esspecially when modding, but nothing gamebreaking.
There's plenty of option to tweak for setting up the world to your playing style, so you can make it way harder or much more forgiving.
Keep in mind a large portion of the game play is highly akin to The Sims, in the sense that you're constantly taking care of your characters needs. Completing certain tasks can get tedious in multi-player without the timeskip function you get in single player, but I think that just adds to the immersion. And the game is way better with friends, so nothing really gets that tedious as long as you're having fun surviving the undead hordes.

A forever early access game that's totally worth it if you like hardcore survival game. Vanilla mode is great, and there's a ton of mods that take it to the next level. 

Even without mods there's a ton of customization. You can tweak the population, the loot, the time of year, the level of erosion, whether water and power turn off immediately, in time, or never. You can adjust the zombies to be traditional Romero zombies, or fast 28 days later zombies. There's even a mode for to have zombies sprint at night (or day) and shuffle during the day (or night) for a I am Legend vibe. It can even be a decent farming simulator if you turn zombies off. 

Highly recommend for zombie survival fans

Project zomboid is kind of hard to review. Any elements you may have issue with the base game is completely up for interpretation whether its intended to be that way and you just suck, or it's poorly designed.  


Its the end of the world and you are presumably the last man standing in whatever town you choose. Like, do you really fault them that you'd need to study a million hours, deal with water shutting off, or just be unlucky enough to pull into a house with 30 zomboids? That's just a real scenario.


Even if you die alot and think you're doing ass, it almost becomes the point of the game. Rolling the dice and watching sims die. Maybe quickly. Maybe after a crazy week long grind. Regardless, its those tense moments that the game shines. That and watching your dumb character in jorts and a wifebeater get mopped.

If you really are just super turned off to that kind of experience, there ARE settings you can mess with. With the right settings you can pretty much have just a "a sort of stop watch" sims 1 remake. Would really like to see more put towards that actually. It'd be neat having a pre apocolypse life simulator and then the option to click back to when SHTF


Over all, most people will probably be perfectly happy buying this. If you're a goof though and can't stand not being given a powerfantasy immeadiately, look elsewhere.

Unbelievable how detailed this game is. I'm usually not much into survival games, but this is incredible. The punishing nature of Project Zomboid keeps you on edge (never let your guard down!), and it's a really addicting feeling when you begin to get the hang of the aspects of the game. 

There is permadeath in the sense that the character is permanently lost when dying, but you can create a new character in the same world. You lose all stats from the previous character though, which is a big deal, and therefore I usually just start over. Starting over after dying from a stupid mistake is actually much more fun than I imagined. Try a new starting location, find another spot for a base, try new builds or strategies, and learn from previous mistakes.

Oh, and the game plays quite good on the Steam Deck as well.

In it's current state, I cannot recommend Project Zomboid. This game has been in development for a well over a decade, and to its credit, this game started out with a really small team. However, as of the most recent build (Build 41 as of writing this) the team has gotten much larger, and a lot of the core development features that are being promised and delayed to further builds instead of being added by popular demand of the community, have already been mods that have existed *well* before Build 41, and even official mod tools. The developers have also been known to ban or outright silence anyone in their public Discord that is giving (more often than not) valid criticisms of the current development path and lack of proper communication from the devs. It's a really fun game, that has so much potential. But as it stands currently I cannot recommend this game in good faith without also telling you to install at least 30 mods so the game is fun and welcoming for you.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I am a 40 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 13 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

You are a person, you are not the hero of the story, not the one to save us all. Its you. You happen to be in the world during a zombie apocalypse. And this is the closest you can get to a zombie Apocalypse for 1 huge factor. Before we get to that, let me talk some more. You are this person, only you. No one else unless you have friends. You seem to be the last person left in your area. You go outside and see zombies, alot of zombies. You can choose to die, or fight. I wont get into alot of detail on what you should do for survival or a entire guide but the one thing that makes this game so real is that when you find a shelter, get food, build a nice house. There is nothing really else you could do, and that is what makes it realistic. Its not like most zombies game where even if you have a shelter you are trying to always achieve a goal. its just you. That is what makes people stop playing. After you did everything, thats it. Now events will happen over time. But they all stop happening after awhile. And that means you can just live forever. Now is it hard to survive? Yes. but is it impossible? No. Most negative reviews tell on how bad the game is after you do all of your goals. I can agree. Lets hope the next update adds something we can do after the goals. But for now just keep surviving because you never know what can happen next.

DISCLAIMER: This game as of this comment is still a WIP. Mods help to bridge the gap a bit (or even a lot, actually), but it is still very rough around the edges at times.

With that out of the way... This game fucking rules. I don't know why, but even when I die, I still have fun losing all that progress. There is so much to go around for immersing yourself and having fun surviving the zombie hoards and progressing your way through. Play 'easy mode' first, and gradually ramp up the difficulty, and that has been my experience so far. It's just... fun! 

Every now and again I've also gone mod-hunting and added a new mod or two and now I'm easily in the hundreds of mods. It's just... Little fixes for little issues or gameplay changes that are fun or neat or give a better taste then the default game that still needs time to bake...

Playing a role of sorts can also be pretty fun for imagining what your character might do given their situation and what not. Put limits, challenges, w/e. It's got a lot of replayability when you try to focus a certain kind of gameplay style for a specific character until death or 'success.' The youtuber community also does a decent job of selling the stories the game can tell, which makes it even easier to be invested in the game via that method. (Got me interested, then a sale happened I couldn't control myself and bought it. xP)

Before I've known what happened I've already got 203 hours in the game... Just. BAM. Time sink. I've only done 3 characters so far, but I'm enjoying the process so far. There is just so much you can tweak about the gameplay to make it challenging or not challenging in certain ways - so if you find a mechanic or gameplay aspect to be unpleasant you can likely change it or mod it to fit your needs.

For a little gameplay context: My first character I played unmodded. I kinda just stuck it out in one town and was gradually getting a nice base set up in the very house I started in. Gradually upping my skills, my stats, my growing dragon-hoard of resources through frequent looting and killing the local zombies... (I've turned zombie respawning off since I felt that made the game more real/fun to me and kept it off.) Then the helicopter event happened... and since I had lots of ammo and I felt pretty confident about fighting the zombies up to this point and the local area should have been... relatively clear, I decided to take it on. It worked out pretty well for a good 10 minutes.... but the zombies kept coming, and they didn't stop coming... I got my shotgun out and started blasting... I thought surely the swarms would peter out a bit after blasting the hoards for a while... but... more kept coming. and before I knew it, my character was getting exhausted, their obese fat ass huffing and puffing and running around and shooting haphazardly and before I knew it... I was caught, and dragged down to be devoured. AAH! First defeat: I was too cocky.

...So I rolled up character #2... After a very heavy modding spree. This time I picked a bit of a remote area and set up my home base and cleared the zombies out of a much larger area in case of future helicopter events. Worked out great! I was doing super well and gradually becoming OP and shit... except I died by dismantling a stairway underneath me that I had built on the outside of my house and fell to my death. Ooph. TBF, I had fallen once already so I was in bad shape before hand but... yeah. That one kinda sucked. Second defeat... Incautious stupidity.

Third character! ... Uh. Well, I couldn't find a nice place to set up a base (I was too picky...) So I ended up camping out in a school bus with an interior from the RV Interior mod. I was doing pretty solid for the resources I'd gathered and was peaking a lot faster thanks to certain advantages. Character was ripped~ ... But I got greedy. I thought I could handle the amped up zombie swarms I'd set to spawn, and for the most part I had been right. Except... my character was getting not exhausted, but actually sleepy-tired, plus I had my bags full of loot from my latest haul and I didn't want to drop it all... and ran into a swarm of zombies that had migrated into the area right next to my van... I tried to get in the van but was cut off by a zombie... tried to back away while fighting them off, but my character was rapidly getting exhausted from all the loot they were carrying + tiredness so their dmg output sunk down so fast... and soon the zombies converged on them despite their still surprisingly effective blows and caught them, I tried to run one more time, but they grabbed and dragged her down... devoured! ... My third defeat. To Greed.

... I'm planning on rolling up my fourth character with a world full of intact cars and plenty of fuel... and the speed demon trait. I'm going to run over so many zombies. 

Anyway, uh... I hope you enjoyed the brief tangent. I recommend this game. A lot. Have fun~!

Although it is still in Early Access with a price tag of $15, I would say it is worth getting considering how much content available it offers on both current patch and beta patch right now. This game, in my opinion, is a hyper realistic zombie survival sandbox with a lot of interesting systems that works pretty well together and I would say that it has more complex game mechanics than most survival game out there.

Pros: 
- Custom configurations for the sandbox world to fit the needs of each player and make the game have the infinite replayability.
- Different modes are available to choose like single player, self hosting peer to peer server, dedicated server and especially support local split screen co-op, which works pretty well with Steam Remote Play Together.
- A huge map to explore, each place offers a different loot spawn distribution, as well as different aesthetic reflected on building and furniture style. More portion of the map is added each major patch and the devs are also planning to make a pseudo-infinite map where the edges of the map are filled with unexplored nature wild land, instead of abrupt dark border.
- The world feels real and alive with a lot of systems that goes hand in hand, like weather and time of the day that affects fishing and foraging, zombies thickly spawn within the big city, gunshots or helicopters that lure away the zombies, etc.
- Progression system or leveling system, although is a pain to go through, it seems reasonable enough to not feel like a chore or a factor just to extend the playtime and replace the main experience.
- This game has one of the most active modding community, with a lot of brilliant ideas to transform the game into a different experience, whether it is addition to game mechanics, QoL, or new map location.
- On the developer side, they are super active on continuing on with new features and stick to their roadmap. Although the updates are slow and very infrequent, they always make sure to keep players up to date with their bi-weekly Thursdoid blog to show the progress and they have always delivered quality updates in the past.

Cons:
- Multiplayer was reworked to be much better than before, but it still feels a bit of a desync from time to time.
- Zombies even with the most difficult configuration can be easy to predict, which would make the game easier the more you play.
- Building system is available, but there are still a few amount of bugs that players have to work around.
- No official server hosted by the developers.
- Although a tutorial is available, there aren't any real directions for new players. There are a lot of system that has a lot of impact on a playthrough, but never was mentioned or explained to, though it makes sense that this is not their main priority at the moment.

This is by far the best zombie sandbox game I have ever played. 

It's packed with so many intricate concepts and it only continues to get better. If you're looking for a game where there's realistic survival aspects like eating, drinking, mood regulation, weather effects, building, crafting, enormous maps with thousands of places to loot or to turn into a base, skills to level up, skills like fishing, mechanics (yes you can work on cars and drive them), carpentry, farming, metalworking, first aid, weapon skills like blunt weapons and bladed weapons, cooking, etc. Then this game is definitely one for you! It is a steep learning curve but I think it's well worth it! For $20, you should give it a shot.

There are some things I wish they would add like some NPCS here and there, like traders or survivors passing by the area or potential NPC raiders or animals for farming and hunting but I did hear that that may be in the works somewhere. So we shall see! Also check out the mods, there are some great mods for the game! Good luck surviving out there!

Project Zomboid tries to hide its mediocrity behind cringey "Early Access, please be nice" on a 10+ year old, $40 game with a full development team.  Full stop.

Project Zomboid is overpriced, badly balanced, makes its systems annoying to manage basic gameplay, and difficult to enjoy.  Provided good / bad Trait misinformation is worse than nothing at all, melee and ranged combat is janky and never improves, the car system is more punishing than rewarding, farming / fishing is tacked on with 0 gameplay elements, and the inventory management is objectively bad and reminds me of games from 25 years ago.  You literally spend the majority of your time weighing your boredom with grinding skills against risk of dying in shitty combat mechanics.  Then there are rAnDoM eVEnTs that basically frenzy zombies and force you indoors for even more boring non-gameplay--or you can try to just keep playing and then be forced to start all over when a group of 25 zombies swarms you.  

THAT SAID:  if you feel like being generous with your time, you can visit the vast mod community that makes this game worth playing.  There's a mod for just about everything under the sun, from making inventory management tolerable, cars that have variety, weapons that don't feel useless (combat will stay fundamentally awkward), food and fishing mods that make the game less of a completely unfun chore after the power and water go off.  There is tremendous depth to this game in terms of replayability and gameplay, but you need to go to third party mod developers to find it.

The people collecting money for this game have plainly been doing little more than milking lukewarm updates for a steady paycheck for over a decade.  They boast "free updates" but the updates are overwhelmingly garbage that nobody needs or wants and does nothing for creating a zombie game.  The next big mod is supposed to be "farm animals", in one of the most obvious failures of prioritization and time management.  The developers do not use or allude to any project map.  If you download this game, you should be prepared to receive nothing of value besides generic Stardew Valley chores being tacked on.

This game has you, buildings, zombies and cars. That's about it. I could go into a whole rant about how methodically boring combat and skill grinding is, how long it takes to kill zombies (four times as long if your character is a bit sleepy), but I can't be stuffed and I don't really want to spend much more time on this game. The crafting system is a very wide and restrictively shallow puddle. There are no NPCs, dogs (despite ubiquitous doghouses), zombie dogs, vehicles other than cars, zombie animals, animals in general, special types of zombies, really the game lacks anything interesting that would shake up gameplay. I still found it kind of absorbing for a while but eventually discovered that on default settings the entire world is swarming with an endless tide of eagle-eyed and bat-eared undead, especially, for some strange reason, in the middle of small-population rural satellite towns and the deep forest. Whut?

Also, for some reason my character takes half an hour in real time to find a stick and a rock in the forest with which to craft a stone axe. I can't say that I recommend this game.

Great game.
A few points:
1. Even though the game doesn't explain anything to you (except a couple of vital tips in a tutorial), the core mechanics are rather basic, which makes the game a bit stale once you clock ~200 hours in it (even with all those challenges). That is until you decide to install 150 mods, that will turn a game about hitting zombies with a crowbar and collecting rainwater into a full-scale Factorio/Silent Hill/Stardew Valley-type of product. The mods create a whole new experience and there's literally anything you could think of. From cars to the ability to shit your pants (literally). Maps, vehicles, new mechanics, clothes, weapons, you name it. PZ also allows you to change sandbox options. If you want every single zombie to carry a gun with ammo, every single car to have keys in the ignition with a full tank and don't want zombies on the map whatsoever, you can do it.
2.  The game gets updates rarely. And it could be a big issue, but the amount of mods the community releases weekly negates it. The developers are planning to release build 42 sometime this year, though.
3. Multiplayer sometimes is a pain in the ass. If you are planning to jump on your private server with your friends, get ready for lags and disconnects. Worth mentioning though that I tried to play on HEAVILY modded private servers, so there's the chance that you will not have the issues I had.
4. The game works the same way Mount and Blade works, more or less. It doesn't try to entertain you, you have to do it yourself and set your own goals. The game also doesn't have any sort of finale (your death is what you can call a 'finale'). 
But this aspect could be changed with mods.  

Overall, it is probably the best zombie survival game out there. The next update should be immense and the only thing I'm afraid of is the amount of mods I will have to delete/update after the release.

I will be completely honest here:  This is a well-made game. It does what it sets out to do exceedingly well, especially given the small amount of HD space it takes up and the low cost.  

BUT due to the very nature of the game I'm finding it stressful, and the aching of my body from being constantly on edge while playing is difficult to tolerate.  What I'm saying is that the game is causing me physical pain. 

As such I would only recommend it to specifically those who enjoy survival horror and / or roguelike games.  Anyone who gets invested in their characters or progress in games would probably do well to give this a miss... as well as anyone easily disheartened by failure.   This is a game that can bring about enjoyment, pain and depression in equal measure. 
It is also worth noting that while this has controller support, it is kinda bad...  and playing Mouse & WASD causes me severe RSI, which just added to the overall physical discomfort. 

Plus despite my opinion of this game generally being a pained positive, I will note that the EULA and general tone the game takes towards the player is a little too sarcastic and antagonistic.   Just because you're bigging up the "everyone dies eventually" angle is no reason to be mocking about it. 

Anyway... yeah, I've said my bit.

I love this game. I've played the heck out of this game. I think it's number two total hours played for my library. Great game! But... 

This game has been around and around. Revisiting the game years on, I keep thinking, 'WTF, this hasn't been fixed yet??'... For example: 1) Grinding 2 months in game just to die to a zombie bite while stuck in an animation while climbing through a window across a table... stupid. 2) Grinding 2 months in game to accidentally auto climb over a wall you're not even facing to have your face eaten by Z's on the other side... dumb. 3) Vehicles can be really annoying, getting stuck on bushes in tall grass, etc. not shifting to the next gear and actually slowing down for no reason... WTF... 4) Right clicking to cook and being shown a massive list of ingredients that goes off the page with little numbers that make no sense... Come on. JUST FIX THIS STUFF.

I'm okay with permadeath, it makes this game super intense, which I love. But, you gotta make the combat super slick to have a fighting chance... which, 10 years into this game's development... it's not super slick, it's kinda' just OK... 

Will revisit again in a couple of months when I forget how frustrating it is to die while stuck in an animation...

When i first saw footage of project zomboid I was immediately intrigued. The depth in mechanics, the complexity of just staying alive, let alone surviving zombies. 

At first i struggled. A lot. I still do but something just keeps bringing me back. 
Maybe its the fact that the developers provided consistent updates, it's a labour of love and it shows. Perhaps its the curiosity of how I will next succumb to a death. 

I've taken the time to make different settings based on different zombie lore. 
Realism being somewhat close to real time with only walking zombies that have little to no sense of direction or smell. No re-spawning gives me the feeling that i'm genuinely alone in the world. 
The point being, you can dictate the play, the world is yours.

I haven't even mention the skills and crafting yet and believe me when I say I have went these 60 hours with barely any focus on them. Partly because I don't normally survive long enough to work on them but ultimately because its fun anyway. There's also multiplayer and a multitude of mods which only add to the depth. 

Tip: hold right mouse while pressing E to open doors. That way you are ready to swing your weapon!

Simply put, Mods carry this game (even for a 10 year old early access game) . The only people who don't think so are autistic to the point where doing taxes would be equal to the same fun as Zomboid. I actually enjoy the difficulty and I don't shy away from difficult games. But a lot of mechanics don't have any micro aspect of the game that is fun and repeatable. The difficulty is all in the macro where it doesn't matter the end game and It's the RPG equivalent of Spongebob and Patrick sitting in the box of "Imagination". 

Essentially, the game is well put together from an RPG stat-based game. One of the best on the market right now. But taking out skill input and barely any end game makes the game a snooze-fest. If you want the alcohol version of video games, play zomboid.

But if you want to know, what I don't like about the game inside the game excluding my personal preferences (I have more hours on another account), I'd say the skill system is pretty bad. To have so many that take so much grinding in a non-perpetual system that is tedious to say the least is not necessarily fun.  Things like carpentry take forever to level up and the lvl 10 rewards of getting there is pretty lame. I also don't see the purpose for many of the skills themselves, especially when you can pick up furniture. The games interface as well is actually piss poor for something that has been in development for 10 years. 

I personally think the no-hand holding, and non-easy mode intuitiveness is of course what someone people like that gives this game positive reviews. But I would personally say that, there is a right and a wrong way of making a game like this difficult and unforgiving, and the philosophy behind how they thought it should be today, is not what I would agree with. It's personally really sad that this type of bare-bones, realistic, "simulation" type zomboid survival game is great but malnourished within the gaming industry. So I kinda blame the industry for not having something better than zomboid and we have to wait years for another attempt at this type of game. But if you enjoy games that are hard without actually making you physically exert yourself and enjoy arbitrary stats and prep resource management, you'd have a field day.

This game continues to amaze me every time I play. Project Zomboid has left my expectations in the dust. The more I play and learn, the more I realize how little I have experienced. It just astounds me how much can be accomplished with every piece of loot I come across. From fixing your vehicle, building animal traps, fixing a broken melee/range weapon, or ingredients for cooking. There seems to always be many uses to any object you can pick up. I really enjoy all of the sandbox settings available. Especially all of the Zombie lore and Advanced zombies settings. I can easily see myself gaining 1000 hours still getting excited when I start a new game. All of these settings in my arsenal makes this game play ever changing. If you find yourself feeling bored playing, well, just start new and create new zeds that sprint! Maybe you only want them active at night. Maaaaybe you want them to migrate in massive hordes. Turn of the zombie re-spawn, and try to secure a town. Honestly if you get bored it's because you don't allow yourself to tread blindly into the unknown. This game is built for you to die, and you will MANY times. Thankfully PZ gives you the option to start a new character in the same timeline, or you can start a whole new game. So if you had a good run with a character and you aren't ready to let go of all the loot. Just create a new character and go enjoy all your shiny. Lastly, traits. I was a bit skeptical at first, but they have grown on me. It's not just buffs/debuffs. They add details to a life before the apocalypse started. Allowing you to form a life story for the character you create. Then you die. 

It's hard for me to have a dislike for PZ. There isn't anything I would want changed that can't be done by mods. I believe Project Zomboid is top star. I'll have sand in all the creases from playing this game.

Project Zomboid is a great game (currently build 41). I say this as someone who has put almost 700 hours into both the vanilla and the modded experience. Why do I keep coming back to this game? There are so many reasons.

First, the game is very well made. The graphics are just good enough that they don't hold back the game play and the loot management is done right. You spawn into a world (either a vanilla world or you create a sandbox world with your own parameters), and then you survive in a zombie infested town. Find a weapon, learn to fight small groups of zeds, find a car, establish a suitable base, find a generator and a source of gas, and survive (cook, grow food, improve your skills and fitness, etc.) 

Project Zomboid feels good to play: the combat (after a slight learning curve) is tough, but fair, the amount of things you can loot is extremely varied, and the map is huge (and keeps getting bigger). Whether single player or multiplayer, the amount of content here is staggering (and a bit overwhelming on a first play-through). 

The game also offers a lot in the way of base building. The carpentry and metal working skills allow you to bolster a preexisting structure, or simply build and entire structure from scratch. You can build walls and windows, plumb a sink to rain collector barrels for fresh water, grow and cook your own food, and trap animals for meat. 

This game also has a great modding community. There are mods for almost anything you can think of. Anything from small quality of life mods, to huge game changing mods that add new vehicles, new weapons, and some even adding game objectives.

The only thing I'm slightly dissatisfied with is the endgame, which can feel a little boring once you've established a functioning base and have good weapons. The devs do plan on adding more late game content for build 42 (animal husbandry, masonry, machining, blacksmithing, so I'm sure the endgame will be a lot more interesting with these implementations.

Project Zomboid is a game for someone with an imagination that enjoys a challenge. It's a game I keep coming back to for its tense atmosphere, it's engaging world and its great community. For anyone interested in this game, I would suggest starting in sandbox mode, enabling multi-hit (so your weapons can hit multiple zeds, and turning off zombie respawns, as this can become tedious if you're struggling with the combat.)

PZ is my favorite game, and I'm always happy to tell people about it! Don't let the Sims 1 graphics fool you: this is a cleverly made experience in being a normal person -- not a superhero -- in the zombie apocalypse. The difficulty is customizable, even before the expanded options of mods. 

A mysterious illness broke out on July 1st, 1993. The radio said everyone in Kentucky should quarantine and go to ground. 8 days later, you emerge, your stores of food exhausted. You find that your entire city has been turned into the <s>walking</s> shambling dead. You are alone.

The musical score beautifully compensates for the dated graphics, giving such a pull into the atmosphere that you can feel truly immersed, even if you usually don't go for isometric views. This game IS a beautiful time-sink. Give it a go.

If you like the concept of a zom-poc game, give PZ a go. If you like Dwarf Fortress*, Rimworld, or Kenshi: also give PZ a shot. If you don't know or care but you're somehow reading this, give this game a shot.

If you're on the fence, and you have a friend with the game, use Steam's Remote Play option to try before you buy..

*All of these games follow DF's philosophy of "losing is fun!"

If you already have the game or if you want to buy it, you must know that this game requires a lot of patience and a great desire to win. Not really to win because your only goal is to survive for a long period of time. But the fascinating thing about this game is the wide variety of ways you can survive. You can do whatever you want, you can stay in a rural area surviving on natural resources, or if you feel stronger you can visit large cities. And if you get bored of the game, you can test the hundreds of modes on the workshop, which can add real fun and challenges to the game. Despite all of this, I personally recommend the game 100%.
This is one of the zombie games of all time.

This game is pointlessly too hard. Even if you're not just spawned into a crowd of zombies, you are AN ADULT with all the skills of a new born baby. Oh, you have three levels in carpentry? Sorry, you literally can't do anything without a screwdriver. Having a secondary weapon is pointless apparently, and you're just going to wave a wrench at zombies like you're saying hello instead of hitting them if your skill is less than maxed I guess... Seriously... How do you not give ANY advantages to your players? The tutorial sucks. It SUUUUUCKS. "We're gonna teach you to do things you literally can't do in the game, then kill you. Figure it out, bitch!" Did you find a book to give some skill an xp boost? Stand still for an hour (in real time) to read it. Nothing saying "having fun in a video game" quite like "stand still, do nothing, leave your pc in the real world to go do dishes, come back, and your character is still reading." Good news though, you're now an expert at finding twigs. Oh, by the way... you can also find lipstick everywhere. Them and those twigs you can't stop foraging should create something of use, right?! Survive on it! So far, Project Zomboid is just another example of how survival games are made pointlessly difficult. At least the graphics are low poly, so your 4080Ti can handle it. Can you right click your way through the zombie apocalypse? No? Then save yourself $20, or go buy a game that doesn't feel like the devs made it simply because they enjoy reading negative reviews. Maybe this game is better online, but the single player mode makes me wish I could get a refund. I've killed many characters, and frankly... the only fun I've had is killing said characters on purpose. Not worth the money.

While this game's statement is to put realism at the forefront, it is just not true. It puts being annoyingly hard as its first mission, then uses realism as an excuse to appear plausible.

Beds do not have sheets on them 90% of the time. Why? Because you can use sheets to cover windows. It would make the game too easy if you had enough bedsheets, so the game starves you of them. Never mind that there is no realistic reason for them missing.

Kitchens filled to the brim with cans are almost always missing a can opener. This is because the game needs you to go from house to house to risk being killed, never mind it's completely unexplainable otherwise.

Public places festering with zeds... while all doors and windows are closed. Is there a story here, like a survivor let 20 zombies enter, then closed all the doors and then let themselves be killed? Is that a frequent occurrence Knox Country?

The investigative instinct of zombies matches the one of Vince Gilligan's characters. If they could browse the internet, they would find your location through your IP address and pay you a visit. A lot of times I would break line of sight in crouch mode for a minute and they would still be on the chase.

All these things, plus melee combat (the core of this game) being reductive and clunky just destroy my immersion.

"You can customize your game how you want though", yes, I did, and the only thing I realized is that everything is extremely slow, boring and uninviting. Dying was the only thing that kept me from noticing that before. Everything, from reading books to building, is just watching bars fill slowly(even at max speed). This game needs to kill you over and over to keep you from noticing you are bored.

Beating all the odds stacked against you is the only engagement you're gonna have. The game knows it, hence the "this is how you died" at the start: you cannot avoid your fate, only postpone it. If it was possible for you to win, if there was a cure against zombification even in the form of amputating an arm bitten by a zombie, the game would just be tedious.

tl;dr: this game is immersion-breaking, boring at best and needlessly frustrating at its worst. Terrible, one-dimensional combat. You can do an infinite amount of things, and they are all equally uninviting. Not for me.

Project Zomboid was first released as a tech demo in April 2011, before releasing on Steam in November 2013. It had something of a rocky ride in those early years, with the game being leaked and, an infamous story at the time, the theft of two laptops containing a bunch of code which hadn't been backed up: Developers The Indie Stone would, rather winningly, go on to give an industry talk titled 'How (Not) To Make a Game'.

It now looks like Indie Stone will need to write another presentation: How to turn your passion project into a viral hit ten-and-a-half years after release. While everyone else was scoffing turkey and leftovers, Project Zomboid's player numbers have been going through the roof. The cause is a major update that pretty much overhauls the game from the ground-up.

It can't be over-emphasised how much Build 41 improved Project Zomboid. Among many other things it introduced a new animation and movement system, vastly improved multiplayer functionality, a new city, a new combat system, a bunch of new systems for things like injuries and foraging, and too many other things to list. It almost feels like the developer could have just stuck a 2 on the end and sold this as the sequel.

The rise in players coincides with the build's release: in November 2021 it averaged around 7,000 daily players, a highly respectable figure for an indie game anyway, but from early December the player numbers start to go through the roof. Zomboid had never broken five figures before but on December 9 the test branch of this new update was released and it smashed through.
